Why: One of the biggest rules in writing good titles is “be clear, not clever.” This title may be toeing that line, but it works because it’s a fun way to show something is fragile, instead of saying it (which is typically much more powerful). Curiosity – This title builds curiosity because it makes you want more details about why you need to be gentle with it and why the creator said, “Yikes!” There’s also contrast between “be gentle” and “Titanium”. Negativity – This is a warning and hints that this product is not as good as you might think. Timeliness – This video was published the day after this phone was released, so everybody was eager for news about it.

Title: The New King of Fried Chicken?! ($1,000 Startup)
Framework: The New King of [Entity]?! ([Accessible Description])
Why: New – People love news and new things, and this title leads with “New”. Desire – The thumbnail gets the audience excited with “$250,000 Per Month” and the title makes it feel more accessible with “$1,000 Startup”. Curiosity – This thumbnail builds curiosity by asking a question.

Title: Farmer Exposes Behind the Scenes Food Industry Scandals
Framework: (Authority Figure) Exposes Behind the Scenes (Industry) Scandals
Why: Authority – Because this is coming from a farmer, this story is more believable. Negativity – People love drama and this title promises lots of it. Curiosity – “Behind the Scenes” makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret.

Title: $6M/Year Business at 20… Luck or Secret?
Why: The best YouTube titles make a bold statement that make you say, “Really? No way!” then you’ve gotta click to find out. This title finishing with “Luck or Secret?” isn’t bold and isn’t tangible enough to make you click. Plus, the title and thumbnail say the same thing — they don’t work together to build even more curiosity. Here are some other ways they could’ve written this title: They could’ve focused on the fact that he knew a secret: “He Built A $6M/Year Business After Learning This Secret” They could’ve focused on the constraint of him being so young: “He Sold $9,000,000 Before He Turned 20” Or they could’ve appealed to a deep desire that many people have: “$6M/Year Business at 20 Following His Passion” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 100 Hours to realize you can do THIS in Spider Man 2
Framework: (Time Frame) to realize you can do THIS in (Entity)
Why: Curiosity – This opens a loop because it makes you want to know what “THIS” is. And the thumbnail is a picture of something about to happen, which adds more curiosity and tension. Time Frame – This is an example of input bias because this creator putting “100 Hours” into Spider Man 2 to learn this makes us value it more.

Title: Improve Your Reading and Listening Skills With This Strategy
Framework: Improve Your (Activity) Skills With This Strategy
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to improve their reading and listening skills. Curiosity – This title opens a loop because it makes you wonder what “this strategy” is. The thumbnail builds curiosity because it asks a question.

Title: I Survived The World’s Coldest Town (-97°F, -72°C)
Framework: I Survived The World’s (Extreme Entity)
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity because it’s extreme and unique: “The World’s Coldest Town“ Negativity – The harsh conditions pictured in the thumbnail and word “Survived” leverages fear to get the audience to click.

Title: All religions explained in 10 minutes
Framework: All (Complex Topic) explained in 10 minutes
Why:
Time Frame – The time frame of “in 10 minutes” brings two benefits to this title: It makes this video feel more tangible (which makes it more interesting).



It increases your desire to watch it because it’s a complex topic explained in a relatively short time. Curiosity – The contrast between “all religions” (a complex topic) and “explained in 10 minutes” builds curiosity.

Title: How to REALLY Increase Your IELTS, TOEIC & TOEFL Scores
Why: I’m not in this niche, but I feel like this might be a pretty narrow topic. But in addition to the potentially narrow topic, this title could be better. The word “REALLY” doesn’t provide any benefit to the audience. Here are a few simple ways they could’ve rewritten this title: “How to Increase Your IELTS, TOEIC & TOEFL Scores As A Beginner” “How to Increase Your IELTS, TOEIC & TOEFL Scores In 1 Hour” “How to Increase Your IELTS, TOEIC & TOEFL Scores Without Spending Hours Practicing” “How to Increase Your IELTS, TOEIC & TOEFL Scores In 2024” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 5 Things I Don’t Do In My Home As A Pro Interior Designer | Julie Khuu
Framework: 5 Things I Don’t Do In My (Possession) As A (Professional)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – This leverages a bit of fear because the audience wants to know if they’re doing something wrong. Authority – This title brings credibility because she says she’s a “Pro Interior Designer” and she’s talking about what she doesn’t do in her own home.

Title: I spent a year searching for the weirdest music tech
Framework: I spent a year searching for the weirdest (Thing)
Why: Time Frame – Input Bias is a psychology term that means we value something more when somebody puts a lot of time into something, so the time frame of “a year” makes you feel like this video is going to be more valuable than just “I searched for the weirdest music tech.” Curiosity – Using words like “weird”, and making them extreme (the weirdest) are two ways to build curiosity.

Title: 5 Signs He’s Emotionally COMMITTED To You
Framework: 5 Signs (Deep Desire)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience wants to know that their guy is emotionally committed to them. This is a great example of using words that your audience uses and describing their goals and desires in a way that makes them feel understood. “Signs” – The word “Signs” is a word that often does well on YouTube.

Title: I Learned Blender in a Week
Framework: I Learned (Complex, Desirable Thing) in (Short Time Frame)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to learn blender. Time Frame – The time frame of “in a Week” makes this video more tangible, impressive, and interesting.

Title: How To Thrift Like A Boss for Artwork and Home Decor | Julie Khuu
Why: I love experimenting and trying new things, but this seems like it was one of the cases where the experiment didn’t pan out. Most of the videos on her channel seem to be educational lists where the video has very clear value and structure. This thumbnail text tells you this video is a vlog, which may not fit what the audience is expecting and looking for from this creator. And to make things worse, the title and thumbnail are both busy and complex, which makes it hard to process when you’re quickly skimming through YouTube. The easiest way to make the title clearer and simpler is to focus on one thing. She could’ve taken out the “artwork” and just written: “How To Thrift Like A Boss for Home Decor”. I probably also would’ve taken out “like a boss” because it doesn’t really provide any value to the audience and their interests and instead, I would’ve doubled down on the thrifting part. Maybe something like this: “How To Thrift For Beautiful Home Decor Under $20” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Do you REALLY need Full Frame? (APS -C Vs Full Frame Vs Medium Format)
Framework: Do you REALLY need [Item]? ([Option A] Vs [Option B] Vs [Option C])
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity by asking a common question. The “Vs” at the end also build curiosity because you want to see how they compare.

Title: The NEW LOOK Golden State Warriors Are A PROBLEM
Framework: The NEW LOOK (Entity) (Exciting Description)
Why: Timeliness – People love news and new things. The Warriors got some new players this offseason and this video was published the day after their first preseason game, so it was everybody’s first chance to see the “NEW LOOK Golden State Warriors”. Negativity – The word “PROBLEM” is dramatic in a good way. Desire – Even though this title says the Warriors are a “PROBLEM”, it means they’re awesome, and since this channel is a channel about the Warriors, the audience loves it.

Title: Just Bury Bananas in the Garden and This Happens
Framework: Just (Simple Action) and This Happens
Why: Curiosity – The title and thumbnail both open a loop because they make you want to what will happen. The thumbnail is amazing because it’s a mid-action shot and it’s a shot of somebdoy doing something a little odd.

Title: Why you Must NOT Shoot Medics in War
Framework: Why you Must NOT (Seemingly Obvious Activity You Would Do)
Why: Curiosity – This is counterintuitive because you would assume you can shoot anybody in war. A simple way to build curiosity is to tell people what not to do, instead of telling them what to do.

Title: Do THIS around your toilet (GENIUS new flooring hack!)
Why: The thumbnail earlier in this newsletter from this same channel about pouring Dollar Store gems into ice water shows something simple. And this title is about a new flooring “hack”… But getting on your hands and knees and painting your entire bathroom floor does not feel like a simple hack. Plus, the thumbnail of pouring Dollar Store gems into ice water shows something just about to happen, while this thumbnail kinda uses the same strategy, it’s not as clear and simple, so it’s not as effective. So the biggest lesson from this video is if you’re showing a hack, make it simple and easy. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: A 16-Year-Old Guitar Store Owner Sold Me An INCREDIBLE Guitar
Framework: A (Unexpected Person) (Action) Me An INCREDIBLE (Entity)
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity two ways: 1) A “16-Year-Old Guitar Store Owner” is unexpected because that’s so young to be a store owner. 2) It opens a loop because you want to know what the guitar is. (The thumbnail adds to this by showing only the back of the guitar). Desire – This creator’s audience loves incredible guitars.

Title: Huge Lies New Home Builders Are Telling You!
Framework: Huge Lies (Authority Figures) Are Telling You!
Why: Negativity – “Huge Lies” leverages fear and grabs the audience’s attention. Curiosity – This title opens a loop because you want to know what lies you’re being told. Authority – New Home Builders have a lot of power in the home-buying process and the real estate market, so if they’re lying to you it’s a big deal.

Title: I Made Huberman’s Morning Routine Work For An Average Person (myself)
Framework: I Made [Authority Figure]’s [Recommendation or Routine] Work For An Average Person (myself)
Why: Authority – Dropping Huberman’s name grabs the attention of people wanting to try his routine (AKA the whole internet right now because he’s blowing up). Desire – This creator’s audience is interested in or wants to try Huberman’s morning routine. Refute Objection – A lot of people think, “I’d love to try Huberman’s morning routine, but it’s too hard.” But this creator saying she made it work for “An Average Person (myself)” gets rid of that excuse.

Title: Someone Called the GAME WARDEN Because I Was Catching Giant Fish!
Framework: Someone Called the (Authorities) Because I Was (Awesome Activity)!
Why: Authority – Calling the game warden increases the magnitude of what’s going on here. Negativity – This title promises a lot of drama, which people love. Desire – This creator’s audience would love to catch such big fish that somebody calls the game warden on them. Curiosity – “Giant Fish” and the thumbnail only showing a splash and an arrow build curiosity because they make you wonder what type of fish was caught.

Title: The 5 Chords Every Guitar Player Should Know
Why:
This is a decent title and a proven topic, so why did it flop? First, this video is more education-focused, whereas videos that have done well on this channel, like “A 16-Year-Old Guitar Store Owner Sold Me An INCREDIBLE Guitar” are more entertainment-focused. This doesn’t fit the audience’s expectations, which makes it harder for the video to succeed. Second, the title and thumbnail could be better — they’re a little plain. A few title options could be: The 5 Chords Every Beginner Guitar Player Should Know



The Only 5 Chords Beginner Guitar Players Need To Know



The 5 Chords Every Guitar Player Should Know In 2024



Learn The 5 Chords Every Guitar Player Should Know (In 8 Minutes) A few thumbnail options could be: Swapping out the number 5 in the current thumbnail for text saying “Simple”, “Easy”, or “Takes 10 Minutes”



Someone playing a common or popular chord with an arrow and text saying “Stop This”



A two-panel thumbnail showing the wrong and right chords, with a red X and a green check All this being said, this is an example of how good ideas don’t always pan out, but keep going because you can figure it out and grow your channel by learning from what works and what doesn’t. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: BOYFRIEND DOES MY VOICEOVER (Makeup Tutorial)
Framework: [Person] Does [Unexpected or Opposite Thing] ([Activity] Tutorial)
Why: Curiosity – The contrast of boyfriend and makeup tutorial voiceover builds curiosity and adds humor here.

Title: American tries GREGGS for the first time
Framework: (Person) tries (Foreign Thing) for the first time
Why: Curiosity – Just like the previous video, the contrast of “American” and “Greggs” (A popular British spot) builds curiosity and humor.

Title: The Hunt for the King of the Dark Web
Framework: The Hunt for the King of the (Negative Entity)
Why: Negativity – People love drama and this title promises a lot of it, plus “King of the Dark Web” is a pretty scary name. Epic – “The King of the Dark Web” feels epic and makes this video much more interesting. Curiosity – The picture of the guy with his eyes blacked out and his name make you wonder who he is and what he did.

Title: The Mirror Principle | If You Don’t Change This, Reality Will Never Change
Framework: The (Named Principle) | If You Don’t Change This, (Entity) Will Never Change
Why: Curiosity – This opens a loop because it doesn’t tell you what “This” is, so you have to click to find out. Desire – This creator’s audience wants to change reality. Negativity – This is a bit of a warning, which grabs the audience’s attention and makes them want to click.

Title: My Current Favorite Lipsticks
Why:
This probably flopped for two reasons: 1) It doesn’t really fit with the rest of the videos on the channel. The others are funny challenges or awkward situations, then there’s this list of lipsticks. 2) The title is pretty boring. She could’ve spiced it up by: Using the current year



Positioning this video as ranking the best and worst lipsticks



Or even titling it as her favorite lipstick in the world, and maybe in the video talking about several different ones for different situations Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: when living below your means seems *IMPOSSIBLE* (how to get by) | MONEY SAVING TIPS
Framework: When [Best Practice] seems *IMPOSSIBLE* (how to [Achieve Goal])
Why: Negativity – This title is all about a deep, specific problem the audience is experiencing. Calling it out grabs the audience’s attention and gets them interested in this video.

Title: How I see the US after living in Europe for 2 Years
Framework: How I see (Entity) after (Activity) for (Time Frame)
Why: Curiosity – This title opens a loop because it makes you want to see the difference between the US and Europe. Time Frame & Credibility – The time frame of “living in Europe for 2 Years” adds credibility because it’s not just a tourist’s opinion — he’s actually lived in Europe for a couple of years.

Title: Once you visualize correctly, the shift happens IMMEDIATELY. (this is how.)
Framework: Once you [Activity] correctly, [End Goal] happens IMMEDIATELY. (this is how.)
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity by using two open loops: 1) It doesn’t tell you how to achieve this shift, so you have to click and watch. 2) It also promises that you’ll achieve an amazing, but open-ended goal, so your mind starts to wander and imagine your own “shift”. (Using specific goals in titles also works very well, but this builds so much wonder, curiosity, and desire that the vagueness works well here. The buzzwords “visualize” and “the shift” also help.) Desire – This creator’s audience wants to learn how to visualize and shift their lives, and they would love to do it immediately (people love speed).

Title: The FIRST Sign of a Magnesium Deficiency Is… (Dr. Berg Explains)
Framework: The FIRST Sign of [Problem] Is… ([Authority Figure] Explains)
Why: Negativity – This leverages fear because the audience doesn’t want to be magnesium deficient. Curiosity – This opens a loop because it doesn’t tell you what the first sign is. Authority – Using this creator’s name (Dr. Berg) builds authority and trust becauses he’s a doctor. Urgency – There’s ugrency here because if you can spot the first sign, then you’re in much better shape than if you have a dozen signs and it’s too late.

Title: The DOPAMINE Myth
Why: The title and thumbnail text are too vague and too similar. There’s nothing tangible that makes you say, “Oh wait, really? I’ve gotta learn more!” One option they could do is to use the thumbnail text, “The Dopamine Myth,” and then have the title be something like, “Dopamine Doesn’t Make You Happy”. Then the thumbnail would support the title, but be different, and might work better because it’s more tangible and challenges your assumptions. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Can I 100% Every Mario Kart Game in 1 Week?
Framework: Can I (Achieve Goal) in 1 Week?
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity by asking a question. Time Frame – The time frame of “in 1 Week” makes this video more tangible and adds a constraint. Both of these make this video more interesting. “Every” – I’m surprised by how often I’ve seen the word “every” pop up in successful videos. I’m assuming it makes the video feel more epic because it adds scale. This isn’t just about a few Mario Kart games, it’s about every Mario Kart game. This same exact format actually got this creator another 2.4 million views a few months ago. The title was, “Can I 100% Every 3D Mario Game in 1 Week?” This is a good reminder to continue doing what works.

Title: How A Silent Album Robbed Spotify Of $20,000
Framework: How A (Counterintuitive Entity) (Negative Action)
Why: Curiosity – A “Silent Album” is an oxymoron. This contrast and counterintuitiveness builds curiosity. Negativity – Robbing Spotify of $20,000 is full of drama and people love drama.

Title: A sewing trick how to sew a zipper correctly without waves
Framework: A (Activity) trick how to (Achieve Goal) without (Problem)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience would love to sew a zipper correctly without waves. Negativity – Calling out the problem (and showing it clearly in the thumbnail) does a great job at grabbing the audience’s interest.

Title: The one regret from high school that I still think about all these years later
Framework: The one regret from (Time Period) that I still think about all these years later
Why: Negativity – The word “Regret” is so powerful and emotional and does a great job at bringing people into your video. Curiosity – This opens a loop because you want to know what the regret is. Relatable – This is such a strong emotional thing that everybody can relate to.

Title: 10 Minute Phrasal Verb Test: Can you pass?
Why: I’ve been speaking English for 32 years and I have no idea what a phrasal verb is. If your audience doesn’t know what something is, they’re probably not going to click. This also might be a small potential audience issue. The first video in this newsletter about “200 Important English Expressions” is applicable to pretty much everybody learning to speak English, but how many people are looking to take a phrasal verb test? To avoid this mistake, use simple words in your titles and talk about topics with a large potential audience. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 9 Legendary Hacks Pro Designers Use in Adobe Illustrator
Framework: 9 Legendary Hacks Pro (Profession) Use in (Tool)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants hacks for Adobe Illustrator. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Authority – This title has more credibility (and makes you want to watch it more) because it’s about hacks that Pro Designers use.

Title: Why So Few Americans Live In This HUGE Area Of The West Coast
Framework: Why (Counterintuitive Fact)
Why: Curiosity – The contrast between “So Few Americans” and “HUGE Area” builds curiosity. Negativity – “‘Empty’ West Coast” in the thumbnail and “So Few” in the title hint at something dramatic or scary. Clarity – This title and thumbnail are simple and clear (more on this in the Flop of the Week below).

Title: 10 STOIC LESSONS TO HANDLE DISRESEPECT (MUST WATCH) | STOICISM
Framework: 10 [Niche] LESSONS TO HANDLE [Problem] (MUST WATCH) | [Niche]
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – This is all about handling a problem: disrespect.

Title: 7 Clues to SPOT the Narcissist EARLY!
Framework: 7 Clues to SPOT the (Problem or Unwanted Person) EARLY!
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – “Narcissist” grabs the audience’s attention and makes them want to click because they don’t want to deal with narcissists. Desire – Most people can spot narcissists, but this creator’s audience wants to spot them early.

Title: Why China Is Building Artificial Islands To Control The South China Sea
Why: The title and thumbnail from this channel featured above are so simple. One glance and you instantly know what the video is about. This title and thumbnail are much more complex. This makes it harder to tell if you’d be interested in this video, so you scroll on by. Plus, this channel’s audience seems to be most interested in American geography. The double whammy of a non-American subject with a complex title and thumbnail landed this video in this week’s flop of the week. To avoid this mistake, make your titles and thumbnails clear and make videos about things you know your audience is interested in. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Facebook is WORSE than You Think: Whistleblower Reveals All | Frances Haugen x Rich Roll
Framework: (Entity) is WORSE than You Think: (Person) Reveals All
Why: Curiosity – This packaging builds curiosity two ways: 1) The title opens a loop and makes you wonder, “How is it worse than I think?” 2) “Reveals All” in the title and “The Truth About Facebook” in the thumbnail make you feel like you’re getting in on a secret. Negativity – There’s lots of drama and fear in this title, which grabs people’s attention and makes them want to click. Confirms Suspicions – There’s already a narrative that Facebook is evil, so when some people see this title they say, “I knew it!”. People love when their suspicions are confirmed. Broadly Appealing – I don’t think Frances Haugen’s name is that well-known (no offense, Frances), so giving her the label “Whistleblower” is an effective strategy. It attracts a broader audience because it’s more easily understood. Obviously they did drop her name at the end, but using her name at the end and the label before it was a good call. “Facebook is WORSE than You Think: Whistleblower Reveals All” is so much more powerful than saying “Facebook is WORSE than You Think: Frances Haugen Reveals All”, right?

Title: The Ultimate 5 Minute DRIBBLING WORKOUT  NBA Ball Handling
Framework: The Ultimate 5 Minute (Activity) WORKOUT (Emoji) (Keywords)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to get better at dribbling. Time Frame – By saying this is the ultimate “5 Minute” dribbling workout, this makes this drill seem more achievable and attractive because it’s so short, and makes this video more interesting because you know exactly what it’ll be about. Authority – The thumbnail has an image of Kyrie Irving, the best ball handler in NBA history.

Title: WEIRD Non-Hobby Tools That’ll Change Your Hobby
Framework: WEIRD Non-(Activity) Tools That’ll Change Your (Activity)
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity two ways: 1) The word “Weird” is a simple way to build curiosity. 2) “Non-Hobby Tools That’ll Change Your Hobby” is counterintuitive. Desire – This creator’s audience loves tools and “Change Your Hobby” hints at improving it. The thumbnail also tells you these are “great” tools.

Title: I watched 151 celebrity house tours and they’re full of lies
Framework: I (Activity) (Amount) (Entity) and they’re full of lies
Why: Credibility – The fact that she watched 151 house tours makes you feel like her opinion is more valid than somebody who’s watched one. This is also because of “input bias,” meaning that we value when somebody put a lot of time into something. Negativity – “They’re full of lies” promises this video will have lots of drama, which people love.

Title: Has Big Tech Doomed Democracy? | Baratunde Thurston X Rich Roll Podcast
Why: The video featured earlier in this newsletter about Facebook worked because people wanted it to be true. I’m wondering if this video flopped partly because the audience are fans of big tech and don’t want this to be true. Also, it’s not very specific. “Big Tech” in the title and “Media” in the thumbnail don’t evoke as much emotion as “Facebook”. Finally, when I first read the title I saw “Baratunde Thurston” and said to myself “What the heck is this word? It’s too long, I’m gonna skip this title.” I didn’t realize it was the guy’s name, I just saw a big word and mentally checked out. (Sorry Baratunde!) Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 21 Old Fashioned Frugal Living Tips to Try Today (that will save you thousands )
Framework: 21 [Descriptive] [Niche] Tips to Try Today (that will [Benefit] [Relevant Emoji])
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This title combines several things this creator’s audience is into: old-fashioned things, frugal living tips, saving thousands.

Title: One building, two sketching techniques| Ink & watercolor tutorial
Framework: One (Entity), two (Techniques) | (Niche) tutorial
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience is into different sketching techniques. Curiosity – This builds curiosity because you want to see how the two different sketching techniques compare to each other.

Title: I got a few inexpensive, but super handy new sewing tools
Framework: I got a few inexpensive, but super handy new (Niche) tools
Why: Desire – Not only does this creator’s audience like sewing tools, but they (and nearly every other audience) likes inexpensive, super handy tools. Curiosity – There’s some contrast between “inexpensive” and “super handy” which builds curiosity and makes this video more interesting.

Title: You’re (Probably) Killing Your Fruit Trees
Framework: You’re (Probably) Killing Your [Possession]
Why: Negativity – Telling people they’re probably killing something they’re trying to grow does a great job at grabbing their attention and getting them to click. And the thumbnail shows something that many people think is good, but has the warning sign over it and text telling them not to do it.

Title: The Windsor Chair…The ULTIMATE Woodworking Challenge
Why: The title says this video is about the windsor chair, but what does the thumbnail say? You can barely see the chair because it’s tiny, dark, and off to the side. Instead, her face takes up most of the frame. If I were to redo this thumbnail, I’d show the chair big and bright and close, and show why it’s the ultimate woodworking challenge. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: What I Wish I Knew BEFORE Moving to Charleston, SC from Ohio
Framework: What I Wish I Knew BEFORE (Action)
Why: Curiosity – This title opens a loop and makes you wonder what he wishes he knew. Negativity – There’s a hint of regret or warning in this title. If you’re considering moving to Charleston, this grabs your attention.

Title: 10 Expensive Looking Color Combinations | Fashion Over 40
Framework: 10 (Desirable Entities)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This is a proven topic for fashion channels — this creator’s audience wants to look expensive (without spending the money to be expensive). But broadly speaking, getting a benefit for cheap is a trend that’s proven across nearly every industry.

Title: The TRUTH about shooting at ISO 100 that the PROS know.
Framework: The TRUTH about (Activity) that the PROS know.
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity two ways: 1) It opens a loop and makes you wonder what the truth is. 2) It makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret and finally learning the truth. Authority – This leverages the authority of the pros to get people more interested in this video.

Title: 11 Of The Most Faked Foods In The World | Big Business | Insider Business
Framework: 11 Of The Most Faked (Items) In The World
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Faked Foods – This brings a bit of drama and curiosity (two of the most powerful click triggers). Epic – “In The World” makes this video feel more epic and fun.

Title: How to photograph the NORTHERN LIGHTS.
Why:
This video flopped because it has a small potential audience. Unless you’re searching for this, you’re probably not going to watch this video. On the other hand, many photographers use ISO 100, so “The TRUTH about shooting at ISO 100 that the PROS know”, featured earlier in this email, can be watched and enjoyed by many photographers. If you want to make videos that get lots of views, you need to have a relatively large potential audience. In addition to this problem, this title is boring. Here are two options for how he could’ve spiced it up: Beginner’s Guide To Photographing the NORTHERN LIGHTS.



How to photograph the NORTHERN LIGHTS In 2023. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: I Created an Anonymous Rapper to “Prove its not Luck”
Framework: I Created an Anonymous (Entity) to “Prove its not Luck”
Why: Curiosity – This title builds so much curiosity because it starts a story and makes you want to know what happened. Credibility – Creating an “anonymous” rapper makes you feel like this will be a legitimate challenge that leads to a (hopefully) replicable result. Refute Objection – A lot of people who want to be music artists probably think it’s luck that other people have made it, so this title tackles that objection head on.

Title: I Tried Zone 2 Training for 3 Months. This Happened
Framework: I Tried (Trend) for 3 Months. This Happened
Why: Curiosity – This title opens a loop and makes you want to know what happened. Timeliness – Zone 2 Training is trending right now, so this video rides that wave. Time Frame – Trying something for a specific time frame makes the video more interesting because it’s more tangible and you know exactly what this video is about. The time frame also helps with this next point. Credibility – Since he actually did zone 2 training for 3 months it makes this video more believable.

Title: 10 Free AI Animation Tools: Bring Images to Life
Framework: 10 Free (Trend) Tools: (Action)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – Not only is this creator’s interested in AI tools, but everybody loves free tools.

Title: Struggles of African Immigrant Working in Canada
Framework: Struggles of (Specific Situation)
Why: This video was a massive breakout from a new channel and I’m not *exactly* sure why it did so well, but I have a few theories: Negativity – People love negativity and drama. Talking about struggles and how a country isn’t worth it definitely fits that. Confirmation – A lot of people in the comments are essentially saying “Yes, I know! This has been my experience too.” When you confirm what lots of people are thinking, but may not be openly talked about, they’ll want to watch and comment. Specific Audience – When you go too specific on YouTube it’s easy to have too small of a potential audience. But people living in Canada, Africans, and immigrants seem to rally around this video saying this is what they’re feeling. If you (and the YouTube algorithm) can find a specific audience that has strong feelings about your content, you can win big.

Title: 7 Generative Fill Techniques You Need To Try
Why:
I don’t think there was one major reason this video flopped, but a combination of several reasons: This video is for Photoshop users. Photoshop is a paid tool, while Midjourney, ChatGPT, and many other AI tools he mentions in his channel are free to use. It’s possible his audience is more into free tools than paid tools.



The title is a little bland. He could spice it up by saying this video is for beginners, it’ll help people make images fast, they don’t have to have any graphic design experience, etc.



The thumbnail is kinda boring. It’s just the Photoshop beta logo, no really cool showing of what it can do. (Yes, it technically shows what generative fill can do, but in a boring and nonobvious way.) Plus, his face is not in the thumbnail. This is important because when you look at his channel, this thumbnail doesn’t really look like it fits the rest of his channel, and he appears to have a pretty strong brand (so putting his face in the thumbnail would probably help). Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The HIDDEN MESSAGE in this Season 4 Scene from the Chosen?
Framework: The HIDDEN MESSAGE in (Entity)?
Why: Curiosity – Talking about “hidden” things is a great way to build curiosity. Timeliness – This video was published soon after the creator of The Chosen released teaser footage previewing season 4.

Title: I created a BARBIE dreamhouse in Animal Crossing!
Framework: I created a (Trending Thing) in (Niche)!
Why: Timeliness – This video was published the day after the Barbie movie was released, so everybody was talking about it. This is an excellent example of trendjacking and applying a seemingly unrelated trend to your niche.

Title: This One-Page Productivity Hack Will Change Your Life
Framework: This (Limited) (Activity or Goal) Hack Will Change Your Life
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants productivity hacks that will change their life. Constraint – The constraint of “one-page” enhances the desire because it seems simple. It also adds curiosity because it makes you wonder how a small thing like a “one-page” productivity hack can change your life.

Title: Stop Wasting Your Money on These 7 USELESS Supplements! | Dr. Steven Gundry
Framework: Stop Wasting Your (Resources) on These 7 USELESS (Tools)
Why: Negativity – Telling your audience to stop doing something they’re currently doing or think is good for them is a great way to get their attention. This also leverages loss aversion because nobody wants to waste money on useless things. Curiosity – This title makes you want to click to learn what these 7 supplements are. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity.

Title: BIGGEST Lies on Food Labels: 3 Ways You’re Being TRICKED With Misleading Food Labels | Dr. Gundry
Why: The title and thumbnail are both too complicated. There’s so much going on that you don’t know what to focus on. You scroll on by because it’s too much work to try to understand what the video is about. If I were to rewrite this title, I’d probably use “3 BIGGEST Lies on Food Labels” *or* “3 Ways You’re Being TRICKED With Misleading Food Labels” (not both, like this title did). Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The Wrong Way to Cross the Border into Canada (NEW BRUNSWICK)
Framework: The Wrong Way To (Nerve-Wracking Activity)
Why: Negativity – This video is about something potentially nerve-wracking, and to make matters worse, they apparently did it the wrong way. Curiosity – This title opens a loop and makes you wonder what happened.

Title: I Worked at REI for 12 Years – Here’s the REI Gear You Should Buy!
Framework: I Worked at (Place) for (Time Frame) – Here’s the (Products) You Should Buy!
Why: Credibility – Sharing that she worked at REI for 12 years makes you trust her more when it comes to REI gear. Time Frame – If she just said she worked at REI, that would add some credibility, but the time frame of 12 years adds even more. Desire – This creator’s audience loves buying gear.

Title: This Is WORSE Than the 1929 and 2008 Yield Curve Inversions
Framework: This Is WORSE Than the (Previous Worst Events)
Why: Normally titles with big words like “yield curve inversions” land in the flop of the week section, but this one works for a few reasons: 1) The thumbnail does a great job of showing exactly what this video is about. 2) This title makes sense even if you take out the complicated words at the end: “This Is WORSE Than the 1929 and 2008” Now here’s what actually got people to click: Negativity – This creator’s audience knows how bad 1929 and 2008 were, so that fear grabs their attention and gets them to click. Timeliness – This video is about what’s happening right now, so it grabs people’s attention.

Title: I Bought Bootleg Nintendo Games from Temu
Framework: I Bought Bootleg (Objects) from (Controversial Store)
Why: Curiosity – “Bootleg” items build curiosity because you never what you’re gonna get. Negativity – Temu has a shady reputation which adds controversy and another element of uncertainty to this video, and “bootleg” adds to the controversy, too.

Title: When Frank Ocean and Tyler The Creator Unite
Why:
There’s no emotion or intrigue here, it’s just a plain statement. They could’ve gone with: A positive angle: “The Magic of Frank Ocean and Tyler The Creator”



A negative angle: “The Downfall of Frank Ocean and Tyler The Creator”



A curiosity angle: “What Really Happened To Frank Ocean & Tyler The Creator” But instead, they with with no angle and it flopped. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: What’s WRONG with the Twitter 𝕏 Logo
Framework: What’s WRONG with (Trending Thing)
Why: Timeliness – This video was published right around the time Elon changed the name from Twitter to X and changed the logo, so everybody was talking about this. Curiosity – This title builds curiosity by asking a question and the thumbnail builds curiosity with the red circle making you wonder what’s wrong with it. Negativity – People are drawn to negativity and drama and critiquing a new logo of a popular company fits this perfectly.

Title: The truth about organic food – according to science | Tim Spector
Framework: The truth about (Topic) – according to (Authority) | (Authority Figure)
Why: Curiosity – “The Truth About” makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret and finally learning “the truth”. This phrase also opens a loop because you need to click to learn the truth. Negativity – The title feels a little ominous and the thumbnail supports that feeling with the text admitting “I Was Wrong”. Authority – “according to science” gives this title a little bit more credibility.

Title: Copper to Champion in ONE STREAM – R6 Ranked Speedrun Attempt
Framework: (Beginner) to (Expert) in ONE (Activity or Unit of Time) – (Keywords)
Why: Constraint – The challenge of going from beginner to expert level in just one stream makes for an entertaining video.

Title: How She Makes $50k a month from Mini-Mailboxes?
Framework: How She (Achieves Goal) from (New and Unlikely Opportunity)?
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience would love to make $50K a month with a business. New Opportunity – New opportunities (like making money with mini-mailboxes) offer hope. People haven’t failed with making money from mini-mailboxes yet, so they’re excited about this new opportunity.

Title: The truth about menopause supplements | Dr Sarah Berry
Why: This title uses the same framework as the organic food title above, so why did it flop? Probably because of the smaller market. Many people in this creator’s audience are interested in organic food, but I’m assuming not as many are currently interested in menopause supplements. I’m not saying views are everything when it comes to YouTube videos, but if getting more views is your goal, it’s important to consider the size of the market. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Rocket Raccoon Sculpture Timelapse – Guardians of the Galaxy
Framework: (Trending Entity) (Activity)
Why: This is a simple example of adapting your content to what’s going on now. This video was published the day before Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 (a popular movie largely about Rocket Raccoon) was released.

Title: How to Avoid Burnout In Your Software Job Search
Framework: How to Avoid (Pain Point) In Your (Activity)
Why: Negativity – This is all about avoiding a pain point (in this case, burnout).

Title: 8 Football Tricks That Have Been BANNED From Football
Framework: 8 (Activity) Tricks That Have Been BANNED From (Entity)
Why: Banned – “Banned” adds curiosity and controversy to this video, which makes it way more interesting than just regular football tricks. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity.

Title: BET YA DIDN’T KNOW YOUR CRICUT COULD DO THIS
Framework: Bet Ya Didn’t Know (Tool) Could Do This
Why: Curiosity – This title opens a loop because it makes you wonder what your Cricut can do. Desire – This creator’s audience loves using their Cricut.

Title: Renting Equipment For DIY Home Improvements| 9 Tips Every DIYer Should Know
Why: I think this video flopped for two reasons: 1) The topic isn’t exactly what his audience watches his channel for. It seems like the videos that do best for him are small DIY house projects anybody can do (like installing an AC unit, the first video in this email), not big projects that require you to rent heavy duty equipment like what the thumbnail shows. 2) The potential audience is small. Many people have window AC units, but much fewer people are willing and able to rent heavy duty equipment for their house projects. To avoid this mistake, know why your audience watches your channel and if your topic has a big enough potential audience. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: What Crops to Sow in June for Self-Sufficiency
Framework: What (Entity) to (Activity) in (Specific Time) for (Goal)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience loves crops and self-sufficiency. Timeliness – This video was published on June 1, when people were thinking about what they could plant in June. Curiosity – This title is a bit of a cliffhanger because it leaves you wanting to know which crops are in the video.

Title: Making A Music Video From Start to Finish (Behind the Scenes, VFX, Color Grading & MORE)
Framework: Making A (Entity) From Start to Finish ([Specific Details])
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to learn how to make music videos and showing them how to make one from start to finish promises a ton of value. It kinda feels like the new version of “The Ultimate Guide” content that got played out in the early days of content marketing. Beginner – Talking about making videos from start to finish also feels very beginner-friendly, and beginners are the biggest, hungriest part of any audience. Length – I’m not saying this is why this video did so well, but it’s interesting to note that this video is ~3 times longer than most of the other videos on this channel. It probably got a ton of watch time and gave the audience time to build a stronger bond with the creator.

Title: $ix Figures My First Year As A YouTuber? True Or False? You Decide…
Framework: (Goal) My First Year As A (Position)? True Or False? You Decide…
Why: This title breaks all the best practices, but it’s such a good idea that it still did well. Here’s why the idea is so good: Desire – Most YouTubers would love to make six figures in their first year. Beginners – Talking about his “first year” relates to beginners, which is the biggest, hungriest group of any audience. Controversy – Many people think it’s impossible to earn six figures in their first year and this creator presses on that with “True Or False?” This question also builds curiosity. Platform Fit – It’s probably worth mentioning that another reason this did so well is that it’s a YouTube video talking about how much he made on YouTube. If this video was about much he made on TikTok, it might not be so powerful.

Title: I secretly learned my mother’s language
Framework: I secretly (Emotional Activity)
Why: Emotion – Speaking her mother’s native language with her hits you right in the feels because it’s so personal. Curiosity – Learning her mother’s language “secretly” builds curiosity because people love secret things.

Title: A Day in the Life of Huw Richards
Why: People watch this channel to learn something that benefits them. The video featured from this channel earlier in this email titled, “What Crops to Sow in June for Self-Sufficiency,” is a good example of this. But this video is creator-focused. This is a good strategy for people like Logan Paul, Emma Chamberlain, or other entertainment creators, but not as much for educational creators. One thing I would try is to position this video as a day in the life of what the audience’s dream is, like this: “A Day in the Life of a Full-Time Farmer” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 8 Small Changes To Improve Your Life Forever
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to improve their life forever. Plus, the “small changes” to improve your life “forever” makes it seem like you’re getting a lot for a little. Curiosity – There’s contrast between “small changes” and “forever”. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity.

Title: I Shouldn’t Be Allowed To Show You This…
Why: I normally don’t like this vague title style, but the thumbnail gives you enough context that the title doesn’t need to spell out what the video is about again. The curiosity (this title promises to reveal a secret) and negativity (the disgusting car and rebellious vibe of the title) combine for successful packaging.

Title: Can A Regular Guy Shoot Better Than A Navy SEAL?
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity two ways: 1) There’s contrast between “regular guy” and “Navy SEAL”. 2) It asks a question.

Title: Guess The Price of These New Construction Homes In Tampa! Which Would You Choose??
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity by asking a question and feels kinda like trivia. Desire – This creator’s audience is into new homes in Tampa.

Title: This Might Be The WORST Idea I’ve Ever Had…
Why: This title doesn’t give enough context for you to be interested in the video unless you’re a big fan of the creator. If you’re going to use a vague title (like this channel did earlier in this email with the dirty car), the thumbnail needs to make it abundantly clear what your video is about. This video has a vague title and a vague thumbnail, which is a recipe to land in the flop of the week. It’s hard for your audience to be interested in a video where they don’t know what it’s about. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: every MIDI keyboard should have this feature in 2023
Why: Curiosity – This title opens a loop because it makes you wonder what “this feature” is. Timeliness – Dropping the current year in there lets the audience know this is about new products. Desire – Most audiences love hearing about products and tools.

Title: The Only 10 Exercises Men Need To Build Muscle | 4X Mr Olympia Chris Bumstead
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to build muscle. Specific Audience – Calling out men specifically makes men more likely to watch this video. Curiosity – The constraint of “only 10” makes you wonder what these exercises are and why they’re so special. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Authority – Dropping Chris Bumstead’s achievement of “4X Mr Olympia” adds credibility and authority to make him more believable.

Title: Housing Market Predictions: The 2023 Housing Crash Has Just Begun (It’s Now Completely Illiquid)
Why: Negativity – This title is all about the fear of a housing market crash and the thumbnail adds to that with a warning. Timeliness – Everybody seems to be waiting for a housing crash and putting the current year in there also grabs the audience’s attention. Curiosity – Talking about predictions for the future builds a ton of curiosity.

Title: 20 Thru Hiking Tips in 6 Minutes for Your FIRST Thru Hike
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Time Frame – The time frame of 6 minutes make this video with a lot of tips feel less intimidating. Beginner – Making videos for beginners (in this case, for people looking for their FIRST thru hike) is a great strategy because it attracts a large, specific subset of the audience that is also willing to learn. Desire – This creator’s audience loves thru hikes.

Title: What Does Everyone Misunderstand About Eugenics?
Why: The best titles are written in simple, easy-to-read language. Is “eugenics” a simple word? No. Also, bold statements often work better than questions. If I were to rewrite this title, I’d turn this into a statement with an opinion, instead of just posing a vague question about an intellectual topic. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The biggest myths about emotions, debunked | Lisa Feldman Barrett
Why: Curiosity – Debunking myths is a great way to build curiosity.

Title: BABY GROOT to KING GROOT, explained in 3 minutes!
Why: Timeliness – This video was published 6 days after Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3 was released, so everybody was talking about this at the time. Time Frame – The time frame of “3 minutes” makes you feel like you’re going to understand this complex topic in a short amount of time.

Title: Jordan Peterson’s Thoughts on Andrew Tate
Why: Authority – This is clash of the Controversial Titans right here. Dropping both of their names makes this video irresistible to this audience. Drama – The expression on both of their faces promises this video will be filled with lots of drama.

Title: $420 Dinner in Tokyo – Kobe Beef vs. Matsusaka Beef vs. Kuroge Wagyu
Why: Desire – This channel’s audience loves expensive dinners and fancy steaks (can you still call them steaks at this level?). Curiosity – This title makes you wonder what the outcome of this competition is and which beef is the best. Authority – Although there are no “authority figures” in this title, Wagyu and Kobe are household names that grab people’s attention. Epic – The expensive price tag, Tokyo, and the famous types of beef all make this video feel epic.

Title: The First Cut is the Deepest
Why: This title breaks the #1 rule when it comes to writing titles: Be clear, not clever. This title tells you nothing about what’s in the video, so people don’t click. To avoid making this mistake, be crystal clear about what your video is about in your title. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: How I Manage My Money On A Low Income (Budgeting + Saving)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to know how to manage their money. Specific Audience – By saying this is for people on a low income, this makes this video way more attractive to people on a low income (which is a large potential audience). Negativity – This title calls out a pain point (low income) and promises to help manage it better. Accessible – Like the video above about cheap accessories, this video appeals to a big audience because many people are on a low income.

Title: I Visited the Most Remote Town in the USA (Outside of Alaska)
Why: Extreme – Doing extreme and epic things like this is more interesting than, say, “I Visited A Really Remote Town”. Negativity – “The Most Remote Town” instills a bit of fear and heebie-jeebies, which also makes this video more interesting.

Title: How to INSTANTLY Improve Circulation in Your Feet and Toes
Why: Desire – Not only do many people want to improve the circulation in their feet and toes, but they also want to do it instantly. Curiosity – “Do This” in the thumbnail is a cliffhanger that makes you want to click and find out what “this” is. Negativity – “Bad Circulation?” in the thumbnail calls out a common pain point.

Title: EMERGENCY EPISODE: Ex-Google Officer Finally Speaks Out On The Dangers Of AI! – Mo Gawdat | E252
Why: Negativity – This title hypes up the drama with “EMERGENCY EPISODE” in the beginning and doubles down on it by talking about the dangers of AI. “EMERGENCY EPISODE” also adds urgency to this video to make you want to watch it now. Authority – Since this is from an Ex-Google officer, this title has more credibility. Timeliness – Everybody is talking about AI right now, so this video rides that wave.

Title: The Surprising & Unbelievable Dark Side Of Open Relationships: Aubrey Marcus | E242
Why: Good titles make you say, “Wait, what?!” *Clicks video to find out more* This title makes me say, “There’s a dark side to open relationships? Duh!” There’s no curiosity here because it’s obvious there’s a dark side to open relationships. The best titles are non-obvious. They challenge the audience’s assumptions and show them a new truth. To avoid making this mistake, know what your audience believes to be true and in your title and thumbnail show them they’re actually wrong. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Engineering the perfect ONE TILE city in Cities Skylines!
Why: Constraint – The constraint of “one tile” adds curiosity because you want to know how he did it. Desire – This creator’s audience wants to make (or watch this creator make) a perfect city.

Title: The Sad Story of the Smartest Man Who Ever Lived
Why: Negativity – People love drama and this title promises a lot of it. Curiosity – This title builds curiosity two ways. 1) You would think it’s great to be the “Smartest Man Who Ever Lived”, so the fact that he has a sad story is a bit counterintuitive. 2) The fact that this is about the “Smartest Man Who Ever Lived” adds an element of uniqueness to the story.

Title: i made the same design in every program ever
Why: Curiosity – You want to see what happens in this experiment, so you have to click. Credibility – There’s an element of credibility and believability to this video because it’s not just his opinion on the different design programs, he’s actually making something with them all.

Title: Why You Struggle to ARTICULATE Your Thoughts Clearly. 5 TRUTHS!
Why: Negativity – The pain point of struggling to articulate your thoughts clearly grabs the audience’s attention and makes them want to watch. Curiosity – In addition to this video being about a pain point, this title promises to tell you why you struggle with this pain point, so it makes you want to click and find out why. List – This title finishes off with a list of 5 truths, which makes this video feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and adds some curiosity.

Title: The Tylenol Murders that Terrified America
Why: I think this flopped for two reasons. The first is that I don’t know how believable this is. Yes, murders that terrified America make for a great story that could be successful on YouTube… but do you actually believe that there are Tylenol murders? Tylenol feels too innocent. Nobody is here saying “I knew it! Let me check this out so I can tell my friends.” Now if this video was about vaccine deaths that terrified America, then everybody would be saying “I knew it! Let me check this out so I can tell my friends.” Also, this channel is about tech news and business, not medicine, so this is also about the wrong topic for this channel. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 99% of EXs WILL Come Back and CHASE you IF you do this ONE THING | Scientific Studies Included
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants their exs to come back and chase them. Curiosity – This opens a loop because it doesn’t tell you what “this ONE THING” is, but makes you want to know what it is, so you have to click. 99% – The “99%” catches people’s eyes and adds a bit of curiosity.

Title: Create a Spectacular Quilt with Just Scraps and this Free Pattern!
Why: Desire – This title promises a lot for a little by saying you can get a spectacular quilt with “just scraps” and a “free pattern”.

Title: My CREEPIEST Commission Story [Art + Storytime]
Why: Creepy – People just love creepy stories a lot.

Title: Want to be Rich? DON’T Start a Side Hustle.
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to be rich and the question in the beginning lets the audience know this video is for them. Curiosity – A lot of people want to start side hustles because they want to be rich, so this title telling you not to start a side hustle is counterintuitive to that thought.

Title: Scottie Scheffler Makes This Challenge Look EASY…It’s NOT!
Why: There’s no reason for the audience to watch. This channel is more about education than entertainment, so the audience wants to learn something from these videos. But this title is all entertainment and doesn’t promise any benefit to the audience. To avoid this mistake, know why your audience watches and deliver it to them in every video. Also, if it were me, I’d test “World’s Best Golfer” in place of Scottie Scheffler’s name in the title. I’m not really up to date with current golfers, but “World’s Best Golfer” is more broadly appealing than “Scottie Scheffler” (no offense, Scottie), and they already put his name in the thumbnail. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Mat Armstrong got SCAMMED on his Murcielago project!
Why: Authority – Mat Armstrong is a popular YouTuber in the car niche and this creator’s audience probably knows and likes him. Dropping his name in the title makes them more likely to click. Negativity – People love drama and “SCAMMED” in the title and “THEY LIED…” in the thumbnail promise a lot of it.

Title: Most People Don’t Even Realize That This Is In The Bible
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity three ways: 1) It opens a loop because it doesn’t tell you what “this” is. 2) It makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret and learning the truth about what’s in the bible. 3) There’s contrast between the monster in the thumbnail and what people would expect to be in the bible. Negativity – The scary monster does a great job at grabbing attention.

Title: He Farms 35 Hours a Week By Himself and Makes 6 Figures
Why: Desire – Many people in this creator’s audience would love to make 6 figures farming. Constraint – The constraint of only 35 hours a week and farming by himself builds curiosity because it seems impossible. Time Frame – The time frame of “35 hours a week” makes this video more tangible and, therefore, more interesting.

Title: The Reason I’m Switching to Sony After 14 Years With Canon as a Professional Photographer
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity two ways: 1) You want to know the reason she’s switching from Canon to Sony. 2) Change like this does a great job of starting a story and building curiosity. Drama – There’s a bit of drama here with switching from one brand to another. Time Frame – The time frame of 14 years shows how much experience with Canon she has, which adds to the drama of switching away from it. It also helps with this next point… Credibility – This creator’s opinion holds more weight because she’s a professional photographer and she’s been using Canon for 14 years.

Title: Dear Earth….. You Need Hear This
Why: There’s a fine line between leaving out enough details to build curiosity and leaving out too many details and not getting your audience’s interest. This title doesn’t have enough details. This channel is about the bible, but there are no words in the title or images in the thumbnail to let the audience know that they would like this video. There’s really not much at all in the thumbnail or title that lets you know what this video is about or who it’s for, so relatively few people clicked. To avoid this mistake, make it clear in your title and thumbnail what your video is about and who it’s for. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Eating For $1 A Day (Full Week)
Why: Curiosity – A challenge like this builds curiosity because you want to know how it worked out. Plus, the constraint of just $1 a day adds to the curiosity. Time Frame – Adding a time frame to a challenge like this makes it more tangible (and therefore more interesting). Relatable – Doing cheap challenges like this are more relatable than, say, “Eating for $1,000 A Day (Full Week)”.

Title: I Tried Buying The Cheapest House In California
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity because you want to know how it worked out. And taking things to the extreme (“the cheapest house”) adds to the curiosity because it’s unique.

Title: Underwear SECRETS Every Woman Should LEARN
Why: Curiosity – Talking about secrets is a great way to build curiosity. Specific Audience – This creator calls out specifically who should watch this video with “Every Woman”, which gets more women to click. Provocative Subject – This probably wouldn’t have performed as well as if it was about t-shirt secrets. (Although now that I think about it, maybe it would’ve done well since it’s relatable and everybody wears t-shirts? I think that would all come down to how good the thumbnail is.)

Title: Don’t Move to Seattle,Washington Unless You Can Handle These 6 Things!
Why: Negativity – Warnings do a great job at grabbing our attention and getting us to click. Curiosity – “These 6 Things” opens a loop because it doesn’t specify what the 6 things are, so you have to click to find out. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity.

Title: BEHIND ROCK’S MOST ICONIC GUITAR RIFF: Deep Purple
Why:
This is a similar format to the first video in this email (also from this channel): “STING’S MOST COPIED RIFF – Why it’s so HARD to get it right,” but there are 3 main differences: Negativity often works better than positivity (“most copied” vs. “most iconic” and “why it’s so hard” vs. “behind rock’s most iconic guitar riff”).



There’s not much curiosity here. “Behind rock’s most iconic guitar riff” doesn’t really put any question in your mind, and the thumbnail and title tell you it’s about “Smoke On The Water” by Deep Purple.



I’m not the most knowledgeable when it comes to rock bands, but I know who Sting is and I’ve never heard of Deep Purple. It might’ve been better if they wrote the title as “Behind Rock’s Most Iconic Guitar Riff” and in the thumbnail said something like “This Is Insane” or “This Is Genius!” That would’ve added a little bit more curiosity. They could’ve also added more curiosity or negativity, but I think that simple change would’ve done better with the current packaging idea. And then there’s the fact that this video is half as long as the video about Sting’s most copied riff. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: What Can $1,000 Get in VIETNAM (World’s Cheapest Country)
Why: Curiosity – This title opens a question in the audience’s mind and gets them wondering what $1,000 will get you in Vietnam. Extreme – This video is so much more interesting because it’s about the “world’s cheapest country,” not just a pretty cheap country.

Title: This is REAL Ketchup and its Mind Blowing
Why: Curiosity – This video’s packaging is counterintuitive. The brown stuff is clearly not ketchup, but the thumbnail text and title make you wonder if maybe it actually is ketchup, so you have to click to find out. Later in this email, there’s actually another video that used the exact same strategy.

Title: He lived (and died) through every Backpacker’s WORST Nightmare…
Why: Negativity – This title is full of fear, which does a great job at getting people to click. Curiosity – This title opens a loop and makes you wonder what exactly is a backpacker’s worst nightmare (and what happened to this guy?).

Title: The Hammer, Reinvented.
Why: Curiosity – The thumbnail is counterintuitive. It definitely doesn’t look like a hammer, but when you read the title, you wonder if maybe this is the hammer of the future. New Opportunity – People love new things and this video is apparently about a new hammer.

Title: 5 FATAL Mistakes that left this hiker Stranded until Death (learn from them)
Why:
Most of the videos that do well on this channel are entertaining stories: “The Most Horrific Crime In National Park History” (329K views)



“The Strangest Death in the History of Backpacking” (492K views)



“He lived (and died) through every Backpacker’s WORST Nightmare…” (3M views) Educational lists, like this one, don’t seem to do as well. This channel isn’t that bad (they only have 2 content formats), but I’ve seen many creators treat their channels like a content dumping ground. (I think I got this term from ​@jamierawsthorne​.) They post podcasts, tutorials, vlogs, and whatever else they create on their channel. If it were me, I’d double down on what’s working by creating just one content format, and stop doing everything else. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: How I Went from 3:59 to 2:48 in the MARATHON
Why: Desire – Many people in this creator’s audience want to run a marathon in under 3 hours. Progress – Telling people how you went from point A to point B starts a story and builds curiosity. Credibility – This isn’t just an empty “how to” video, it’s about “How I”, which makes this video more believable.

Title: Train Your Brain To Make More Money Now | Marisa Peer
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to make more money now. Curiosity – There’s something about “train your brain” that feels like a shortcut that could actually work, but it’s mysterious enough that it builds curiosity and makes you want to click.

Title: The 5 New Commercial Aircraft That Will Change The Way We Travel
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Curiosity – “Change” builds curiosity because you know something will be different, but you don’t know what, so you have to click and find out. “New” – People love new things. That’s it, that’s the tweet.

Title: Mix detergent with SALT  You will not believe the incredible result
Why: Curiosity – The title builds curiosity by opening a loop and not telling you what will happen. The thumbnail builds curiosity by showing something that’s just about to happen. Both of these make you feel the need to click and see what happens. Broad audience – Everybody has detergent and salt in their home, so nearly anybody can enjoy this video.

Title: What Was it Like To Fly The SR-71 Blackbird
Why: Do you know what the SR-71 Blackbird is? Yeah, me neither. And although this creator’s audience loves military planes and many of them might know what the SR-71 Blackbird is, it would be more powerful (and easy to read) if they titled this video something like: “What It Was Like To Fly The Fastest Military Plane In History” Giving things labels and taking them to the extreme is a great way to make obscure topics more exciting and easy to understand. Oh… and when you’re making your thumbnails, make sure the text is easy to read. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: How to Make $10,561 / month with Digital Products Using AI
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to make over $10K/month, and making it with digital products using AI makes this possibility even more exciting. Timeliness – This title rides the wave of everybody being excited about AI.

Title: 5 Reasons to Retire as Soon as You Can
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Urgency – This title hints that there’s some urgency to retire, which makes you want to click more. Desire – This creator’s audience wants to retire as soon as they can.

Title: Apple’s New Glasses Are Genius, Here’s Why
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience loves new products. Curiosity – The “Here’s Why” opens a loop that makes you want to click and learn why these glasses are genius. Timeliness – This is about a new product and people love new.

Title: Top 8 Anti-Aging Foods To Eat After 50
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – This video talks about aging, which is a big problem this target audience is facing. Specific Audience – By calling out people over 50, this attracts a specific (but huge) audience, which makes them more likely to click.

Title: I got monetized in 12 weeks – HERE’S HOW I DID IT
Why: This title is good because it’s about achieving a big goal in a specific time frame, right? Well, maybe if this was a YouTube education channel. But it’s not.
