She talks about selling on etsy, digital products, and side hustles. Her audience probably doesn’t know or care what “I got monetized” means. This video probably would’ve done better if she spoke in terms her audience understands. Maybe something like, “I Made $X,XXX On YouTube in 12 weeks – HERE’S HOW I DID IT.” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: These Triggers Are “The Tell” That You were Neglected and Ostracized As a Child
Why: Curiosity – This title opens a loop because it doesn’t specify what “these triggers” are, so you have to click and find out. Negativity – This picks at a very intense pain point for many people, which makes them want to click and learn more about it.

Title: 12 Free Tools I’d Use to Learn Japanese (If I Could Start Over)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience wants to learn Japanese and “free tools” makes it sound even better. Beginner tips – The “If I Could Start Over” part relates to and attracts beginners, which is the biggest, hungriest part of any audience.

Title: I Made Famous Logos ULTRA Realistic
Why: Curiosity – The realistic logo on the right being blurred out and the title both do a great job at starting a story, but leaving you on a cliffhanger so you have to click and see what they look like and how he did it.

Title: Toyota CEO: “This New Engine Will Destroy The Entire EV Industry!”
Why: Negativity – “Destroy the Entire EV Industry” is full of drama, which grabs people’s attention and makes them click. Timeliness – The fact that this is about a new engine makes this feel like news and tells the audience this is relevant right now. Authority – This uses the position of “Toyota CEO” to grab attention and build credibility.

Title: Tren Maya: Mexico‘s Biggest Megaproject
Why: I think this flopped because it’s a boring idea. The Tren Maya is just a train cutting through the jungle that nobody wants (according to the video). Compare this to the other video in this edition from this channel mentioned earlier about The Cube. It’s a massive golden cube big enough to fit 20 Empire State Buildings inside of it. Because this is a bleh idea, the thumbnail turned out bleh too. The image in the Tren Maya thumbnail is a little unclear. Then, once you realize it’s just a path cut in the jungle, it’s unimpressive (and kinda sad if you’re a tree hugger like me). To avoid this mistake, make sure you have a great topic, title and thumbnail before you spend time and money creating your video. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 3 WORDS to USE in your next JOB INTERVIEW for GUARANTEED SUCCESS! (JOB INTERVIEW TIPS!)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience wants tangible tips (3 words to use) and guaranteed success for their interview.

Title: 4 Old Jeans Ideas | DIY Denim Bags and Purse | Compilation | Bag Tutorial | Upcycle Craft
Why: This channel is interesting because she does several videos about individual DIY denim projects, then does a longer compilation video with 4-9 of the projects and that video always does really well.

Title: I Tried A REVERSE Coloring Book?? *It SOLD OUT??*
Why: Curiosity – This is about a proven topic (coloring books), but there’s a twist because it’s a *reverse* coloring book. The fact that it sold out adds curiosity and drama.

Title: 7 FATAL Wiring Mistakes Most DIYers Don’t Know They Are Making | Most Are Guilty of 3
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – Not only is this about mistakes, but “FATAL” increase the stakes and adds more fear to this. Curiosity – “Most DIYers Don’t Know They Are Making” makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret.

Title: TRAVEL AGENT Interview Questions & ANSWERS! (How to PASS a Travel Agent or CONSULTANT Interview!)
Why: This title flopped in the short term because it caters to such a narrow audience. Anybody can get value from the title mentioned earlier in this email (“3 WORDS to USE in your next JOB INTERVIEW for GUARANTEED SUCCESS!”), but this video is only for travel agents. It’ll probably rank well in search and get views over these next few years, but there is this question: Is it worth it to make such niche videos that will get a few views each month when you could instead focus on broader-appeal videos that may get more views overall? Many creators have to ask themselves that question and it’ll be different based on each keyword and your monetization strategy. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: MLB’s Most Overrated Player: The Rise and Fall of Javier Báez…
Why: Extreme – People on YouTube love extremes. In this case, the “most overrated player” worked well (not just “a really overrated player”). Negativity – People love to hear drama-filled stories like this one.

Title: How To Grow Jalapeño Peppers (For Beginners) From Seed To Harvest – Pepper Geek
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to grow jalapeno peppers. Beginners – Making this video specifically for beginners attracts the biggest, hungriest subset of the audience.

Title: The REAL Reason Why Jewish People Reject Jesus As The Messiah
Why: Curiosity – This title makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret. Negativity – This is the car crash effect in action. People are drawn to drama.

Title: The $300 Street Photography Camera No One Knows About
Why: Curiosity – This title makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret. Desire – This creator’s audience loves cameras, especially relatively cheap ones.

Title: Pregnancy Checklist: How to Plan for Birth
Why: This channel is all about productivity, finance, and self-improvement. This video about pregnancy doesn’t really fit with what the audience watches this channel for. Plus, pregnancy is pretty niche compared to the above topics, too. So to avoid this mistake, know why your audience watches your channel and deliver on that. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The Dark Side of Minimalism: “Decluttering Ruined My Life”
Why: Negativity – People love drama and this title is full of it. Timeliness – Minimalism and decluttering are popular trends right now. Curiosity – Most people think minimalism and decluttering is great, but this title is counterintuitive and claims that it’s bad.

Title: Haircare Mistakes That Will RUIN Your Hair
Why: Negativity – Nobody wants to make mistakes or ruin their hair, and this title uses that to get people to click. The thumbnail also adds to the negativity with a warning.

Title: 12 Reasons People REGRET Moving To North Carolina
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – Nobody wants to have regrets, and this title uses that to its advantage.

Title: This SIMPLE TRICK Changed Everything for me
Why: Desire – People love “simple tricks”, and “Changed Everything” is open-ended (which builds curiosity), but sounds like something cool happened. Curiosity – This title is a cliffhanger because it doesn’t specify what the trick is. Specific Audience – The thumbnail calls out people over 40, which makes them more likely to click.

Title: HOW MUCH MONEY DID WE SAVE? | No-Spend Challenge | minimalism + frugal living
Why: I think this flopped for two reasons: 1) It’s too complicated. It’s not easy to instantly read and understand, so people scroll on by. 2) This may have been a bad topic for her channel. It seems like her audience is into minimalism and frugalism. Although they’re kinda the same thing as saving money, they have a slightly different vibe. To avoid these mistakes, have simple, clear titles, and know your audience and why they watch your channel. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: I ordered HelloFresh to see if it was a scam.
Why: Curiosity – This title hints that HelloFresh might be a scam, but it’s a cliffhanger that makes you wonder what the final verdict is. Negativity – Talking about products being a scam does a great job at grabbing the audience’s attention.

Title: How Stoics Deal With Loneliness
Why: Authority – This creator’s audience wants to be like the Stoics. Negativity – This is all about a problem people deal with.

Title: The Sharpest Object In The World Can’t Cut Anything
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity two ways: 1) It’s about something extreme and unique: the sharpest object in the world. 2) It’s counterintuitive. You would assume the sharpest object in the world can cut anything.

Title: Polestar 3 first look: Possibly the best looking new EV for 2023
Why: Timeliness – “First Look” and “new EV” lets the audience know this is about something new coming in the future. Desire – This creator’s audience likes new cars. Curiosity – By saying this is the “best looking” it builds curiosity because it’s unique. And that curiosity is enhanced by only showing a part of the car in the thumbnail.

Title: The Fraught History of Re-Usable Rocketry
Why: I like to think I’m a pretty smart guy, but when I read this title, I had to read it twice. Fraught means… not good, right? And re-usable rocketry… that’s what Elon is doing, right? Titles need to be understood instantly because people are mindlessly scrolling YouTube. I think it might’ve been better written as: “The Dark History of Re-Usable Rockets.” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The BEST R6 Attacker NOBODY Plays…
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity two ways. 1) There’s contrast between “Best R6 Attacker” and “NOBODY Plays”. 2) The title doesn’t specify who that attacker is, so you have to click to find out. Desire – This creator’s audience is interested in good R6 attackers.

Title: Do collagen supplements really work?  Dermatologist @DrDrayzday
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity by asking a question. Desire – This creator’s audience wants to know if collagen supplements really work. Authority – This title drops the creator’s profession in at the end to get people to trust her content.

Title: TSA Line Mistakes in 2023 (travel tips for airport security)
Why: Negativity – Nobody wants to make mistakes, and this title benefits from that. This video is also about one of the most frustrating things about flying: the TSA line. Timeliness – Dropping “2023” in there lets the audience know this is relevant right now. Desire – This title finishes off by telling the audience they’ll get the main thing they watch this channel for: travel tips.

Title: Meet a 23-year old from India running a $20,000,000 company in the US
Why: Curiosity – There’s contrast between “23-year-old” and “running a $20,000,000 company”, as well as the fact that this guy is from India, but running a big company in the US. Desire – This creator’s audience would love to run a $20,000,000 company. Plus, everybody likes a good underdog story because they can relate and be encouraged that they can do the same. Authority & credibility – This 23-year-old isn’t just running a small company — $20,000,000 adds authority and credibility that proves he’s legit and you can learn something from him.

Title: 5 INVESTING HABITS That Will Make You A Millionaire (DO THIS IN 2023) | Jaspreet Singh
Why: This title has it all: a list, a big desire, the current year, and it’s about habits (one of my favorite topics). So why did this flop? Well, the title is a little longer than many of the other recent titles, so that could be it. But honestly, I think this is just a good example that even if you write a great title, your videos won’t always go viral. Make the best title and thumbnail you can, and make the best video you can, then let YouTube do its thing. If you get 1% better with each video and don’t give up, you can make it on YouTube. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 8 Tools I Regret Not Buying Sooner
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – Instead of saying “8 Tools I Love”, this creator said, “8 Tools I Regret Not Buying Sooner”. Everybody wants to avoid regrets and this creator uses that to their advantage here. Desire – Almost every niche loves videos about tools.

Title: 10 Things You Should Avoid Revealing In A Job Interview – Interview Tips
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – This title is a warning against revealing the wrong things in an interview.

Title: 3 Sewing Projects to MAKE and SELL To make in under 10 minutes
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience loves sewing projects and selling their projects. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Time Frame – The short time frame of 10 minutes increases the desire to make these projects because it makes them seem easier and more achievable. *Note: It looks like they used poor wording with “to make” in there twice, but this is such a powerful framework that’s worked for this channel multiple times that apparently it doesn’t really matter.

Title: Slowest & Fastest Star WR 40-Yard Dash Times!
Why: Curiosity – The contrast between “slowest & fastest” grabs your attention. Timeliness – This video was published right before the NFL combine started. Desire – NFL fans are much more interested in 40-Yard Dash times than the other combine events, like the broad jump, for example. Authority – They mentioned “Star WR,” not just “WR,” to grab the audience’s attention. Retention note: The times get progressively faster so you want to keep watching to see the fastest times, and they started with some popular players at first to grab your attention.

Title: Complete Hewn flooring installation guide
Why:
This video has a small potential audience compared to the rest of the videos on this channel. Unless you’re specifically looking to install Hewn flooring (whatever that is), you probably don’t care about this video. Contrast that to videos that almost everybody can watch and enjoy, like: 8 Tools I Regret Not Buying Sooner



This tool does more than you think



I screwed up a simple table To avoid making this mistake yourself, consider the size of the potential audience for your topic before you make the video. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Title: Toyota Bet EVERYTHING To Destroy German Luxury
Why: Negativity – This title is full of drama. Epic – Betting “everything” increases the stakes and makes this video more interesting.

Title: I wish every Christian could watch this.
Why: Curiosity – This is a cliffhanger that makes you wonder what this video is about. Specific Audience – By calling out Christians, this creator makes Christians — his ideal audience — more likely to watch this video.

Title: Make Your Yard ANT FREE FOREVER In 3 Easy Steps
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants an ant-free yard. Negativity – This title is all about a pain point: ants in your yard. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity.

Title: $599 M2 Mac Mini vs $13,000 Mac Pro | DaVinci Resolve Battle
Why: Curiosity – The contrast between the relatively inexpensive $599 M2 Mac Mini and the expensive $13,000 Mac Pro builds curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience loves DaVinci Resolve and Mac products. X vs. Y – Everybody loves a little competition, especially when it’s a competition between two opposite opponents. In this case, a cheap vs. expensive option.

Title: The Cringiest Fast & Furious Movies RANKED | IDEALIST
Why: This channel is about cars — only cars. Not movies about cars. A mistake many creators make is making videos about topics their audience isn’t interested in. Or, at least, isn’t interested in hearing about from them. It could be a big difference, like if a fitness channel giving financial advice, or a small difference, like this example. The key to avoiding this mistake is knowing why your audience watches your channel and delivering that. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 5 Reasons why you should NOT move to Chicago
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Curiosity – This video is counterintuitive because it’s a Chicago real estate agent telling you why you should not move to Chicago. Negativity – Telling people why they should NOT move to Chicago will often grab their attention more than if you tell them that they should move to Chicago.

Title: The Single FASTEST Way To Improve As A Producer
Why: Desire – Not only does this creator’s audience want to improve as a producer, they want to improve fast. Curiosity – This title says there is a single fastest way to improve as a producer, but doesn’t specify what it is, so you need to click to find out.

Title: 6 Outdated Trends to Ditch in 2023 & What to Wear Instead
Why: Timeliness – This video was published in the beginning of 2023, so this tells the audience this video is about current trends. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – Nobody wants to wear outdated clothes.

Title: 6 Dirty Secrets Backpackers Refuse To Talk About
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Curiosity – “Secrets” that people “Refuse To Talk About” builds a ton of curiosity here because you feel like you’re getting scandalous insider information. Negativity – The fact that these are “dirty” secrets makes this title so much more exciting.

Title: We Finally Know How To Eat Cactus Without Getting Poked
Why: Ah yes, the cactus-eating video I’ve been waiting for! I’m not exactly a foodie, so maybe there’s some delicious cactus trend I’m unaware of, but I don’t think this video has a large potential audience. To avoid this mistake yourself, research your video’s topic and make sure your audience will be interested in it before you make the video. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The Best Workout Routine for Beginners
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants the best workout routine. Beginner – Videos for beginners do well because they’re the biggest, hungriest part of any audience.

Title: Quit your 9-5 with these 3 Etsy Store Ideas – Six Figure Strategies
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to quit their 9-5. Negativity – This title is all about moving away from pain — “Quit your 9-5″. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Curiosity – This title mentions “these 3 Etsy Store Ideas”, but doesn’t specify what they are, which builds curiosity by opening a loop.

Title: I’ve Never LOVED An iPhone Case More
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience love tech accessories. Curiosity – This title is a cliff-hanger — why does he love this one so much? Extreme – This title is a big, bold statement, which typically does better on YouTube than weaker statements (“I Really LOVED This iPhone Case,” for example).

Title: HABITS to Break the NEGATIVE Programming of Your MIND! | Joe Dispenza | Top 10 Rules
Why: Negativity – This title is about moving away from pain — “Break the Negative Programming of Your Mind.” Plus, there’s a bit of “stick it to the man” vibes, fear, and conspiracy here with the “Programming of Your Mind” part. List – This title finishes off with a list, which builds curiosity and makes this video more tangible.

Title: $60 DIGITAL NOMAD hotel in Kuala Lumpur
Why: A $60 hotel is pretty unremarkable. Even if a $60 hotel is the “best hotel in KL” (like the thumbnail says) or expensive for KL, $60 is too average to grab most people’s attention. If it was a $5 hotel or $1,000 hotel, those prices would probably do a better job at getting the audience’s attention. Plus, these creators broke the “Show, Don’t Tell” rule in the thumbnail. They’re telling me in the thumbnail that it’s the best hotel in KL, but they certainly aren’t showing me (what am I even looking at?). Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: NEW Ak-47 in Rainbow Six Siege
Why: Timeliness & Desire – People love new things. That’s it, that’s the tweet.

Title: 23 INSANELY CHEAP Destinations for Budget Travel in 2023
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience loves travel destinations. But not only that, they also love cheap travel destinations. Talking about inexpensive things caters to the broadest audience (not everybody can afford expensive things) in a way that people want them (inexpensive). Timeliness – This video was published at the end of 2022, when everybody was thinking about travel plans for 2023.

Title: Belly Fat, Insulin Resistance, and a Hack to Beat Them Both
Why: Negativity – This title grabs the audience’s attention by mentioning two pain points in the beginning. Desire – This title promises to fix both of those pain points with a single hack.

Title: 11 Section layouts to make your website ultra UNIQUE
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience loves section layouts to make their website unique.

Title: Enjoy the Holidays AND Stay Keto
Why: The most obvious reason this flopped is because it’s boring. The best titles have curiosity, fear, and/or desire, but this title has none of that. But there’s another mistake here: repeating the thumbnail in the title. Thumbnail text should be complementary to the title and work like a 1-2 punch. When you repeat your title in the thumbnail, you’re missing an opportunity to get the audience to click. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: How to Be Less Emotionally Reactive: Black and White Thinking
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to be less emotionally reactive. Negativity – This is about moving away from pain (being less emotionally reactive), rather than towards pleasure (e.g. being more emotionally stable).

Title: MID HANDICAP Golfer BREAKS 80 12 days AFTER USING THIS DRILL!
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience would love to break 80. Time Frame – “12 Days” makes this drill seem even more effective since it works so fast. Specific Audience – If you’re a mid handicap golfer (which the majority of people are), you feel like this video was made for you. Curiosity – This title builds curiosity two ways: 1) It opens a loop with “this drill”. You know this drill is effective, but you don’t know what it is, so you’ve gotta click to find out. 2) It’s counterintuitive that a mid handicap golfer (aka an average golfer) can break 80 (a great score).

Title: CUT HER OFF If She Does These Things During The Dating Stage! (VET HER OUT)
Why: Negativity – This is all about a negative thing, which grabs the audience’s attention. Curiosity – This opens a loop because she talks about the things that mean you should cut her off, but doesn’t tell you what those things are.

Title: Genius YouTube Advice for 15 Minutes Straight…
Why: Desire – This channel’s audience wants genius YouTube advice. Time Frame – “15 Minutes Straight” lets you know exactly what you’re gonna get if you click this video, which makes more people click. Authority – The thumbnail uses authority because it has many of the top YouTubers faces’ on it.

Title: How Genetic Is Mental Illness Actually? Heritability Estimates for Mental Health The Role Genes Play
Why: This title is too wordy and confusing. There are lots of big words that make it hard to read. I think it could’ve been better if she just took everything out after the question mark. To avoid this mistake, make your titles easy to read while skimming. You don’t need to summarize the entire video in your title. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Is it time to buy? Housing Market Update
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity by asking a question. Desire – This creator’s audience loves housing market updates. Timeliness – This is about what’s happening in the housing market right now.

Title: ACCOUNTANT EXPLAINS: Money Habits Keeping You Poor
Why: Negativity – This is all about the fear of staying poor and trying to avoid it. Authority – This video feels more believable because its from an accountant.

Title: This STUDY Changes EVERYTHING We Know About BASS FISHING
Why: Credibility – The fact that this video is about a study makes you feel like it’s legit, so you’re more likely to watch it and trust what it says. Curiosity – This title opens a loop because it starts a story, but doesn’t finish it.

Title: How Fast Can You Touch Water in Every Sonic Game?
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity by asking a question. Negativity – This video is about touching water, which essentially kills Sonic.

Title: Should you consider a 1031 Exchange?
Why: Titles that mention benefits, hopes, and fears typically do better than titles that get into nerdy specifics, like this one. Plus, this video is only 1:42. It seems like either shorts or longer videos work best on YouTube right now… not videos stuck in the middle like this one. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Title: Clermont Florida is going to BOOM (here’s why)
Why: Curiosity – This title also builds curiosity by talking about the future.

Title: I Made 3-Foot Takis
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity because it’s unique and extreme. Desire – Who wouldn’t want a 3-foot Takis?!

Title: Engineering Degree Tier List 2023 (The BEST Engineering Degrees RANKED)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience loves degree rankings. Timeliness – Dropping “2023” in there lets the audience know this is relevant right now.

Title: Things You Only Notice In Starship Troopers As An Adult
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity by making you wonder what these things are. It also kinda makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret. “Adult” – Adult things catch the audience’s attention more because they’re controversial, and people love controversy.

Title: Pecron 1500 Pro Review – Affordable Off Grid Power Option
Why: This title is boring. I’m not saying it’s not effective — it probably attracted buyers for the Pecron 1500 Pro and they probably got lots of affiliate sales. Plus, it’ll probably rank it search and do well in the long term. Buuutttt… they could’ve spiced it up a bit. They could’ve turned it into a story or an experiment to get more views and maybe make more sales. For example, he could’ve talked about how long he survived off the grid using only that power station in a video titled, “I Survived 10 Days Off The Grid With No Power.” (Btw I have no idea how long these things actually last.) Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Thank you for reading and I hope you enjoyed this week’s edition. If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, share your referral link with them. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. Title: TESS Telescope Found New Planets Better than Earth!
Why: Timeliness – This title feels like news and people love news. Curiosity – It’s counterintuitive that there are any planets better than Earth, so that build curiosity.

Title: 10X Your Excel Skills with ChatGPT
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to 10X their Excel skills. Timeliness – ChatGPT is trending like crazy right now, so this title rides that wave.

Title: What $100 Buys at the World’s Most Expensive GROCERY STORE
Why: Curiosity – This title starts a story, but doesn’t finish it, so you need to click and watch the video. Also, “World’s Most Expensive Grocery Store” builds curiosity because it’s extreme.

Title: My Results Walking Every Day || Fat Loss!
Why: Daily Tips – People love hearing about things you can do or have done every day. Time Frame – Time frames make videos more tangible and there are two in the thumbnail: one hour and 30 days. Curiosity – This title makes you want to see his results. Desire – This creator’s audience wants to lose fat.

Title: How to Record Multiple USB Mics at Once
Why: It’s tough to say this video “flopped” because it’s probably meant to rank in search, and therefore is not expected to get many views right away. That being said, I have a few thoughts on this. First, always keep in mind the potential audience size when you’re making a video and make sure it’s worth it for you. In this case, would it make more sense for this creator to spend his time making another video about 10Xing your skills with ChatGPT (see his video above) than a video about recording with multiple mics? Maybe. Second, this title could be spiced up a bit. He could refute an objection (“How to Record Multiple USB Mics at Once without ___”), call out beginners (“How to Record Multiple USB Mics at Once for Beginners”) or used the current year to let the audience know its about what’s working right now (“How to Record Multiple USB Mics at Once in 2023″). Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro.

Title: 3 Essential Arpeggios  (Beginner Piano Lesson)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Beginner Tips – Calling out beginners in the title works well because beginners are the biggest, hungriest part of any audience. Desire – This channel’s audience wants beginner piano lessons.

Title: If this pencil works, it will change your life.
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants amazing pencils. Curiosity – “Change your life” is open-ended and makes you want to know what will change and what’s the effect.

Title: The Entire NBA FEARS The WARRIORS Because of this PLAY!
Why: Negativity – People love hearing about things we fear. Curiosity – “this PLAY” opens a loop because it doesn’t specify what the play is, so you need to watch the video to find out.

Title: 5 Overlocker Tips You Won’t Find in the Manual (my best serger tips!)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Curiosity – This title makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret. Desire – This creator’s audience wants serger tips.

Title: Quit (Quietly)
Why: I’m a little confused about what’s going on here. Is he telling me to quit quietly? Did he quit quietly? Why should I quit quietly? When it comes to titles, clarity is king, and this title broke that commandment. To avoid this mistake, make sure your audience knows what you’re trying to tell them and why in your title. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro.

Title: Women are easily attracted to men who know these things
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity because it doesn’t specify what “these things” are, but gets you interested in them, so you have to click and find out. Desire – This creator’s audience (men) want to easily attract women.

Title: 4 HABITS THAT KEEP GODLY MEN WEAK
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – This is about habits men should avoid that keep them weak.

Title: How To Create 30 Instagram Reels in 24 Hours with Canva
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to create lots of Instagram Reels fast. Time Frame – “in 24 Hours” makes this video feel more tangible and exciting — it’s about creating a lot of reels in a short amount of time.

Title: Mustang GT Dark Horse 2024 is Going to be The Game Changer
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity because it’s talking about a future product, and the future is inherently unknown. Desire – This creator’s audience loves mustangs and new cars. Timeliness – This video was published soon after Ford unveiled their plans for the Mustang GT Dark Horse and everybody was talking about it.

Title: If you’re a Jealous Person, watch this
Why: I think this flopped because nobody gets excited and says, “Hey, I’m a jealous person! This video is for me.” I have a feeling that it would’ve done better if, instead of labeling the person as jealous, it positioned jealousy as a problem that can be fixed. Something like, “Watch This To STOP Feeling Jealous.” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions  here . P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro.

Title: these things helped me escape the matrix
Why: Curiosity – “These things” builds curiosity because she mentions them, but doesn’t specify what they are, so you need to click to find out. Negativity – This video is all about escaping a scary place.

Title: I Ate 100 TBSP Of BUTTER In 10 Days: Here Is What Happened To My BLOOD
Why: Time Frame – “In 10 Days” makes this video feel more tangible. Curiosity – “Here Is What Happened To My Blood” builds curiosity because it’s a cliff-hanger. You want to click and see what happened. Negativity – This title is about doing something many people think is unhealthy, it’s not about how he ate an apple a day for 10 days. Credibility – This video feels very legit because he’s measuring blood, not just sharing how he feels.

Title: Do These 12 Things as Soon as You Get Into Your Cruise Cabin
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Curiosity – “Do These 12 Things” opens a loop because it doesn’t specify what the things are, so you need to click and find out.

Title: 11 Hacks to Make Your Cakes Look Professional
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience want their cakes to look professional and they want hacks to do it.

Title: Dangers of Dry Fasting & Dehydration
Why: This topic just seems obvious (and therefore boring) to me. Of course there are dangers associated with dehydration! If this was about the dangers of Keto or intermittent fasting, which many people are passionate about and assume is good for you, then I bet it would do better. That being said, there could be some health trend that I don’t know about where people think dehydration is good for you. Anyway, this week’s lesson is this: obvious topics don’t normally work well. Be contrarian, challenge your audience’s assumptions, talk about their fears and desires. Just don’t be obvious. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Hope you enjoyed this week’s edition and if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S.
