Title: The GENIUS Reason Why F1 Steering Looks BROKEN
Why: Curiosity – There’s contrast between “genius reason” and “looks broken”, which builds curiosity and interest.

Title: 6 SECRET SEWING TOOLS YOU DID’NT KNOW YOU NEEDED!
Why: Curiosity – This title makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience loves learning about sewing tools.

Title: 10 BIG NFL Names Whose Teammates Are SICK Of Them
Why: Negativity – There’s lots of drama in this title, and people love drama. Authority – “Big NFL Names” grabs your attention more than just “NFL Names”. (Plus it builds curiosity by leaving it open-ended, so you want to know who these players are.) List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity.

Title: I Tested EVERY Colored Pencil in the WORLD!
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience is into colored pencils. Credibility – This title makes you feel like this video is legit, so you’re more likely to watch it. Epic – Testing every colored pencil “in the WORLD!” makes this video feel epic.

Title: 10 Times Fans Were Caught Crying Over Their Team in the Stands
Why: This title and thumbnail don’t fit with the rest on this channel and they don’t call out this channel’s core audience. Every other video on this channel is about the NFL, and these creators make it obvious they’re about the NFL. They have “NFL” in the title and NFL players in the thumbnails. But not this one. So the next time you make a video, make sure it’s about a topic your audience wants to watch on your channel, and make it obvious in the title and thumbnail that your video is about that topic. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Have any questions about the hooks in this edition? Reply to this email and let me know! And if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: VOLUMIZING HAIR PRODUCTS FOR FINE THIN and THINNING HAIR *before and after*
Why: Pain Point – This title calls out “thin and thinning hair”, and if you’re struggling with that, you’re pretty likely to click. Desire – This creator’s audience is into volumizing hair products.

Title: Riding Japan’s $120 Completely Private First Class Bus | Tokyo – Osaka
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience is into private first-class travel. Plus, “$120” in the title makes it feel more tangible.

Title: Lifesteal Finally Unbanned This…
Why: Timely – “Finally Unbanned” makes this video feel like breaking news, and people love breaking news. Curiosity – This title opens a loop by saying Lifesteal unbanned “this”, but not specifying what “this” is. Negativity – The word “unbanned” feels controversial.

Title: How I’d Start a YouTube Channel in 2023
Why: Timeliness – Starting a YouTube channel in 2023 is on many people’s minds right now, so this title rides that wave. Beginners – This is about “starting” a channel, not scaling a channel. It caters to beginners, which are the biggest, hungriest subset of any audience. Desire – This creator’s audience would love to start a YouTube channel in 2023.

Title: Dental School Q&A | Entering My 4th Year!
Why: This title probably flopped for two reasons: its boring and off-topic. It’s boring because there’s no emotion. She could’ve added emotion by talking about the hardest or worst thing about dental school. And it’s off-topic because most of her videos are about clothes, not dental school. So the next time you make a video, make sure its about a topic your audience is interested in watching on your channel and include emotion into the title. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: How to Build Muscle At Any Age (7 TIPS!)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience wants to build muscle, especially as they get older. Refute Objection – This is all about refuting the objection of, “I’m too old to build muscle.” List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity.

Title: The Creepiest Historic Hauntings In The British Isles | Historic Hauntings | Absolute History
Why: Timely – This was published the day before Halloween when everybody was thinking about scary and creepy things. Curiosity – Taking things to the extreme (“The Creepiest” ) builds curiosity because it’s unique. Negativity – This is all about fear and scary things, which grab your attention.

Title: Shark Released Their Hair Styler… OMG!
Why: Curiosity – “…OMG!” opens a loop because it’s vague, but makes you want to know what she thought about the hair styler. Timeliness – This feels like news (people love news) because it’s about a newly-released product.

Title: Forget the Oven, This is How I Make a Prime Rib Now
Why: Negativity – This title is about moving away from the old way of doing things. Curiosity – “This is How I Make a Prime Rib Now” builds curiosity by opening a loop. It’s a cliff-hanger and makes you wonder how he makes prime rib now. Desire – This creator’s audience would love to make prime rib that looks like the one in the thumbnail.

Title: How To Stay Healthy While Traveling (7 TIPS)
Why: I know this is a topic that’s commonly talked about in fitness, but I don’t think it’s that big of a pain point. How much do you really care about eating healthy while you’re traveling? I think building muscle when you’re older (see the video from this creator mentioned earlier) is a much bigger pain point. Plus, the thumbnail doesn’t really look like it’s about fitness. It’s a girl in a bikini with the words “Travel Tips”. Looks like a travel video to me, so this creator’s core audience might just gloss over it. And finally, since this title flopped, I might try to write it from a negative angle. Something like: “Don’t Do This If You Want To Stay Healthy When Traveling” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: My Airbnb Lost Money… Here’s The Truth About Being an Airbnb Host
Why: Negativity – People love seeing negativity, plus this is a fear many people in real estate have. Curiosity – This builds curiosity three ways: 1) It opens a loop with “The Truth About”. 2) “The Truth About” also makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret. 3) Many people think real estate is a great business model that you can easily make money in, so this is counterintuitive to what they think.

Title: The World’s Quickest Cars: Lucid Air Sapphire v Bugatti Chiron v Tesla Plaid – Cammisa’s Drag Race
Why: Curiosity – Taking things to the extreme (“world’s quickest cars”) builds curiosity because it’s unique. X vs. Y – People love competition and want to see how things compare against each other.

Title: Japanese Minimalist: 6 Habits that help me stay minimal
Why: Habits – People love habits because they’re tangible and we can envision easily plugging them into our day. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience wants to stay minimal.

Title: 8 Work From Home Jobs That Are Always Hiring! (Without College)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience is looking for work from home jobs. Refute Objection – Someone might see this and think, “I can’t get a job without a college degree.” But “(Without College)” at the end gets rid of that excuse.

Title: How This Junkyard Chevy Del Ray Is Now Worth $75k | The Appraiser
Why: It seems like they tried to use contrast to build curiosity: “Junkyard Chevy Del Ray” vs. “Worth $75K”. But I think that failed because it’s not abundantly clear. The thumbnail doesn’t look like a junkyard car and many people don’t know what a Chevy Del Ray is. If I were to rewrite it, I would say, “How This Junkyard Car Is Now Worth $75,000”. Contrast this with the title mentioned earlier about the world’s quickest car. In just four words the idea is conveyed. You know exactly what it’s about and (if you’re a car fan) you’re excited about it. So make your titles and thumbnails crystal clear and use simple words. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 5 Things You Should NEVER Tell Coworkers
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – What you should never tell your coworkers makes for a more spicy and interesting video than one about what’s ok to tell your coworkers.

Title: This Food is WORSE than Sugar on a Keto (Low Carb) Diet
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity three ways: 1) It opens a loop by telling you this food is worse than sugar, but not telling you what it is. 2) It makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret because you assume sugar is the worst thing for you on a keto diet. 3) It’s also counterintuitive because of this. Negativity – Talking about foods that are bad for you gets your audience’s attention more than talking about foods that are good for you.

Title: These Home Cameras are NOT Private!
Why: Negativity – This title picks at a very strong fear in our culture right now.

Title: Asking Strangers Their Thoughts On Christianity
Why: Curiosity – This style of video is going crazy on YouTube right now because it makes you want to know what these strangers said. Credibility – There’s an element of credibility to this style of video because it’s not the creator’s opinion — it’s what real people think or have experienced.

Title: Answering Your Career Questions
Why:
This title is too boring. I think it could’ve done better if the creator made it a little spicier. Something like: “Answering Your Embarrassing Career Questions”



“Answering Your Toughest Career Questions” On top of the title being boring, the quotes in the thumbnail are boring, too. “Managing workload” is pretty boring compared to something like, “Horrible Boss”. And “what’s up with the hat?” is kinda funny, but doesn’t make me want to click as much as, say, “2023 interview tips”. Even if she didn’t get interesting questions like this, I’d probably throw them in there because it’ll make for a better video and more clickable thumbnail and title. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The Dumbbell Only 1 Person Could Lift
Why: Curiosity – This title sounds a little too crazy… a dumbbell only 1 person could lift? But it’s also just believable enough that you have to click to see what’s going on. Plus, it’s open ended. Who’s the 1 person? How much does the dumbbell weigh? These questions make you want to click even more. Constraint – “Only 1 Person Could Lift” adds a constraint, which makes for a much more interesting story.

Title: 10 Amazing DIY Christmas Gifts People ACTUALLY Want! (2022)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Timeliness – Lots of people are thinking about Christmas right now and this title rides that wave. Desire – This creator’s audience would love to give Christmas gifts that people actually want.

Title: WHY THEY ARE PICKING FIGHTS WITH YOU!
Why: Negativity – This title and thumbnail are all about addressing a big pain point the audience has.

Title: 4 Social Security Changes That Will Have a BIG IMPACT in 2023
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Curiosity – This title builds curiosity two different ways: it talks about change and the future. Both are unknown and open-ended, so you have to click to learn more. Timeliness – Since it’s near the end of the year, people are looking forward to 2023.

Title: Are Two Narcissists actually “in love?”
Why: Who’s this video about? Narcissists. Who’s probably not watching videos about love because they think they’re the greatest? Narcissists. This is different from the video mentioned earlier titled, “WHY THEY ARE PICKING FIGHTS WITH YOU!” That video is about narcissists’ victims, who are hurting and probably watching more YouTube than the narcissists. So before you make your next video, think about who’s actually watching your videos. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out  Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Towing with my Ford Lightning EV Pickup was a TOTAL DISASTER!
Why: Negativity – People love drama and this title about a total disaster promises the video will have lots of drama. Timeliness – Ford Lightning EV Pickups are new and everybody is interested in what they can do.

Title: Harvard negotiator explains how to argue | Dan Shapiro
Why: Authority – This channel borrows the credibility from this Harvard negotiator to get people to click.

Title: 14 BANNED GADGETS YOU STILL CAN BUY ON AMAZON
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Negativity – “Banned” gadgets make this video so much cooler than just regular gadgets. Curiosity – It’s counterintuitive that can still buy these “banned” gadgets, which builds curiosity and makes you want to click.

Title: I saw my boss do these 10 things in Excel!
Why: Authority – “My Boss” adds a little extra credibility here. Curiosity – This title opens a loop (and builds curiosity) by telling you about “these 10 things in Excel” but not telling you what they are. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity.

Title: HERE’S HOW PROFESSIONALS DEEP CLEAN THINGS
Why: This channel is all about crazy gadgets and inventions (like the banned gadgets video above). You know what it’s not about? How professionals deep clean things. Not that that’s a bad topic, it’s just a bad topic for this channel. So if you don’t want your video to flop, make sure that you’re choosing a topic your audience wants to watch on your channel. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake ( @jthomas__  on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here . P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The Secret Weapon That Got Me $17,000 in VA Disability Benefits
Why: Curiosity – “The Secret Weapon” builds curiosity by making you wonder what it is. Desire – This creator’s audience would love to get $17,000 in VA disability benefits.

Title: You’re Probably Taking your Vitamin D Wrong, and it Could be Dangerous (& Ineffective)
Why: Negativity – This title gets the audience’s attention by giving them a warning.

Title: 5 MYTHS about Bicycle Traveling / Bikepacking vs. Reality // Tips & Tricks // Cycling the World
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible (you know exactly what the video will be about) and they add some curiosity. Curiosity – “Myths” add a lot of curiosity because they’re things you think are true but aren’t, so you want to know what the truth is. *Note: I think this title is too long and if I was using this framework, I’d only model the first part.

Title: 4 ONE-MINUTE Habits That Save Me 20+ Hours a Week | Time Management For Busy People
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible and they add some curiosity. Time Frame – Time frames also make videos feel more tangible and “one-minute habits” is a great example of this. Desire – This creator’s audience loves to save time. Specific Audience – This title calls out a specific audience with “Time Management For Busy People”.

Title: How do you prove a service connection for sinusitis?
Why: A lot of people say that you should make videos about the questions you get from your audience. This feels like that’s what happened here, and this is why I don’t love this advice. In this case, it seems like it’s way too specific of a question to do well on YouTube because it has a small potential audience. So here’s a question I always like to ask myself before coming up with a video idea: is there a big enough potential audience for me to meet my view goals for this video? Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out  Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 7 RED FLAGS You’re Dealing With An Emotionally BROKEN MAN…
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible and add a little bit of curiosity. Negativity – Red flags and the fear of dealing with “an emotionally broken man” grabs the audience’s attention.

Title: 4 Things NOT to Say to Your Therapist
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible and add a little bit of curiosity. Negativity – We’re biologically wired to listen to warnings, and this title leverages that.

Title: 20 Greatest Discontinued Foods of All Time
Why: Curiosity – There’s contrast between “greatest” and “discontinued” and it’s counterintuitive… why would a great food be discontinued? The contrast and counterintuitive both build curiosity. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible and add a little bit of curiosity.

Title: Affordable PREFAB HOMES I Had No Idea Existed!
Why: Curiosity – “I had no idea existed” is a fun way to build curiosity around a subject because it feels like you and the audience are getting in on a secret together. Desire – This creator’s audience is into affordable prefab homes.

Title: The WORST Dating Advice For Women You SHOULD NOT Listen To!
Why: Normally I have a good idea for why a video flopped, but this week I don’t. This video (and my second choice for flop of the week) seems to have a pretty good title. So this is just a reminder that the title isn’t everything. There’s a lot that goes into how successful you are on YouTube. My favorite bit of advice? Get 1% better with every video. Alright, that wraps up this week’s edition of Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: You’re Not Lazy: How to Live a Chaotically Organised Life
Why: Negativity – This title starts out by refuting a self-doubt. Desire – Everyone in this creator’s audience would love to live an organised life. Curiosity – “Chaotically Organised” are opposites, which builds curiosity.

Title: This “Adult Only” Cruise Was The Worst Cruise I’ve Ever Taken | Virgin Voyages
Why: Negativity – People love hearing about drama. Extreme – The “Worst Cruise I’ve Ever Taken” makes for a much better story than just a really bad cruise.

Title: Buddy Valastro Was Never The Same After Cake Boss
Why: Curiosity – “Was Never The Same” opens up a loop and makes you wonder what happened to Buddy.

Title: Stop Standing HERE in Doubles! (why you’re losing)
Why: Curiosity – Many tennis players think it’s good to stand at the spot shown in the thumbnail, so it’s counterintuitive for the creator to say stop standing there. Negativity – Telling your audience to stop doing something common is a great way to get their attention.

Title: 5 Things Every Ex-Child Needs to Hear
Why: I thought this title was funny and clever, but that’s not what get clicks. Clarity beats cleverness every time, and this is a good example of that. So the next time you’re coming up with ideas, ask yourself, is this title crystal clear? Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The ONLY 3 Stretches You Need for Better Flexibility
Why: Desire – This is all about a big desire for her audience. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible and add a little bit of curiosity.

Title: The FED Just Gave a Serious Warning To All Americans With DEBT
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity by starting a story, but not finishing it. You can’t help but wonder what warning the Fed gave after reading this title. Negativity – We’re genetically wired to listen to warnings, and this creator uses that to his advantage in this title. Timeliness – The word “Just” makes this title feel like news, and, in general, we’re more interested in news than education. Authority – “The FED” brings credibility to this video. Specific Audience – If you’re an American with debt (which is a ton of people), then you’re way more likely to watch this video because it feels like this was made just for you.

Title: MIND-BLOWING VINYL HACKS THAT WILL CHANGE THE GAME!
Why: Curiosity – “Mind-Blowing” hacks is a fun (although maybe extreme) way to build curiosity. Desire – This channel’s audience would love vinyl hacks.

Title: My Simple Productivity System (for normal people)!
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience loves simple productivity systems. Specific Audience – By calling out normal people in the title, all us normal people feel like this video was made for us. It also kinda refutes an objection. People might think, “these hacks won’t work for me,” but by ending the title with “(for normal people)”, it gets rid of that excuse.

Title: What Product Marketers ACTUALLY Do in Tech Companies!
Why: The video above (the one about normal people) calls out a massive audience with a great benefit. That’s a good formula for a successful video. But this title is about a much smaller audience (product marketers). I would assume that almost everybody wants a simple productivity system, but much fewer people care about what product marketers actually do at tech companies. Here’s a question I always ask when evaluating an idea (BEFORE making the video): “Does this topic have a big enough audience for my view goals?” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Namibia: A Side Of Africa The Media Won’t Show You
Why: Curiosity – This makes you feel like you’re getting in on a secret. Negativity – This title has an “anti-establishment” or “sticking it to the man” feel to it.

Title: Top 10 CSS One Liners That Will Blow Your Mind
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible and add curiosity. Curiosity – There’s contrast between “one liners” (sounds simple) and “will blow your mind” (sounds incredible). Desire – This channel’s audience would love some amazing CSS one liners.

Title: The Video Credit Card Companies Don’t Want You to See
Why: Curiosity – This builds curiosity by revealing a secret. Negativity – Like the Namibia example above, this gives a big “anti-establishment” vibe.

Title: How To Not Look Frumpy & Older Than You Are-Get Out of That Rut!!
Why: Negativity – This video is all about avoiding an unwanted outcome.

Title: How a South African Who Came From Poverty Changed His Life
Why: The clearest difference between this video (32K views) and the Namibia video above (674K views) is the thumbnail. The Namibia thumbnail is bright and you can clearly see their faces. This thumbnail is dark and the subjects are small. It’s also a little wordy and complicated. To make it simpler and punchier, I would’ve worded it like this: “How a Poor South African Changed His Life”. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 6 Uncomfortable Retirement “Truths” You Need to Hear…
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible and add some curiosity. Negativity – “Uncomfortable Truths” are way more interesting than, say, “Happy Truths”. Curiosity – This title makes you wonder what these “uncomfortable truths” are, so you have to watch.

Title: World’s Steepest Climb Vs World’s Best Climber: Can He Defeat It?
Why: Extreme – Extreme things, like world’s steepest climb and best climber, make for an interesting story. X vs. Y – Everybody loves a little competition and they have to click to see what happened.

Title: Where Else To Self-Publish Books That’s NOT Amazon KDP – Self-Publish Low Content Books
Why: Refute an objection – This channel’s audience might think their only option to self-publish books is Amazon KDP, so they’re interested to hear other options. Curiosity – A simple way to build curiosity is to tell your audience about what something is not, so they have to click and find out what it is.

Title: Food Sticking to Stainless Steel Pans? 4 Common Mistakes to Avoid
Why: Negativity – This title starts with a pain point and then talks about mistakes to avoid. List – Lists make videos feel more tangible and add some curiosity.

Title: Top 5 Ways To Train On Your Commute!
Why: My first thought was that this flopped because it’s a narrow topic — how many people are actually riding their bike to work? But a video titled, “What’s The Best Way To Ride To Work? | GCN Commuter Challenge,” recently did well for this channel (350K views). My theory is that this flopped because those who are riding their bikes to work are doing it because they enjoy it, not because they’re trying to train hard on their way to work. Whether or not that’s true, the lesson is to always strive to know your audience better and understand their goals and motives. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 24 HOURS IN THE CHEAPEST ALL-INCLUSIVE RESORT IN MEXICO (Playa Del Carmen)
Why: Time Frame – People love time frames because they make a video feel more tangible — you know exactly what to expect and that makes you more excited to click on it. Extreme – The “Cheapest All-Inclusive” is much cooler than “A Cheap All-Inclusive” Desire – Even though it’s the cheapest one, this video is still about an all-inclusive resort, which is something this audience loves.

Title: How The YouTube Algorithm Works in 2022
Why: Timeliness – Since the algorithm is always changing, adding “2022” at the end of the title lets the audience know this is relevant right now. Desire – YouTubers are obsessed with the algorithm.

Title: 7 Dividend Stocks That Pay Me $500+ Per Month
Why: List – Lists make a video feel more tangible and add some curiosity. Desire – This creator’s audience loves dividend stocks and loves to get paid every month.

Title: FIX LOWER BACK. BEFORE IT’S IRREVERSIBLE
Why: Negativity – This title is all about a pain point and a warning to go along with it.

Title: Angel Investing, Explained Easy!
Why:
Some topics just have a smaller audience. Here’s a screenshot from Google Trends of Angel Investing vs. Dividend Investing (the topic of a video that crushed it for this channel recently): Knowing that angel investing isn’t exactly the most popular topic, this creator could’ve spice up the title with some curiosity or negativity. Something like: The Best Investment Strategy Nobody Talks About



I Wish I Knew About This Investment Strategy 5 Years Ago Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: The Sudden Rise of UGC
Why: Timeliness – This is about a current trend and it feels like news. People love news. New opportunity – UGC is a new opportunity for people trying to make money online (this creator’s audience). People love new opportunities because they haven’t failed at the new thing yet, so it offers hope. Negativity – This thumbnail sparks fear in the audience.

Title: If Only I Knew This About FASTING 5 Years Ago
Why: Negativity – This is about a regret that this creator has. Curiosity – “If only I knew this…” builds curiosity by opening a loop. What did he wish he knew?!

Title: How to Wake up Before 6am Everyday
Why: Desire – The specific desire of “Wake up Before 6am” is much better than just, “Wake up Early.” Daily – People love things they can plug into their daily routine.

Title: from BROKE to ABUNDANCE mindset | *how this changed my life*
Why: Transformation – From a bad state to a positive state promises a good story and is exactly what the audience wants. Curiosity – This builds curiosity a few ways. First, the “how this changed my life” part adds curiosity by opening a loop. Plus “changed my life” adds curiosity because it’s vague and open to interpretation. And finally, there’s contrast between “broke” and “abundance”.

Title: How MSG Affects the Brain (good, bad, and ugly)
Why:
This probably flopped because it doesn’t take a stance on MSG. Looking at some of his other videos, they’ve either had an opinion (unlike this title’s “good, bad, and ugly”) or built curiosity. The thumbnail is also bland and vague, just like the title. Here are some other angles he could’ve taken with the title: MSG’s Surprising Benefits for Brain Health (positive stance)



STOP Eating These Foods With MSG In Them (negative stance)



This Controversial Ingredient Can Change Your Brain (curiosity driven) Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! And if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: My HONEST Opinion After 1 Month in the Philippines
Why: Time frame – This time frame gives his video credibility because he’s been there an entire month, as opposed to some people who’ve traveled there for just a few days. Curiosity – It might just be me, but the way he uses “HONEST” makes you feel like you’re getting insider information here.

Title: I SURVIVED 50 HOURS W/ LIVER KING…
Why: Authority – Liver King’s name and picture makes a ton of people click. Negativity – “Survived” adds to the feeling that you’re about to watch an intense video with some tough adventures. Time Frame – The time frame of 50 hours makes this video feel more tangible and interesting.

Title: How to LOOK RICH and WEALTHY! Simple tips and tricks to achieve that sophisticated, polished look!
Why: Desire – This creator really nailed down what their audience wants. “How to LOOK RICH and WEALTHY!” is way more specific than just, “How to Look Pretty.” Plus, people love simple tips and tricks.

Title: I Quit Teaching & Here’s What I Learned
Why: Negativity – Quitting something good is a great way to get people’s attention. Curiosity – “Here’s What I Learned” opens a loop and makes you want to find out what she learned. Milestone – Your audience will love hearing about big milestones, like quitting a job.

Title: Your money is cheating on you (with your bank)
Why: This title is a classic example of “clarity > cleverness.” It’s not immediately obvious what she means by, “your money is cheating on you.” And if you can’t instantly understand what a video is about, you’ll keep scrolling right past it. This probably would’ve done better with a clearer title, like, “You’re Losing Money Every Day (thanks to your bank)”. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 17 hours in SINGAPORE CHANGI AIRPORT
Why: Time Frame – People love time frames because they make videos feel more tangible. You can envision exactly how the video will go, which makes you more likely to click. (Note: just because you can envision how the video will go doesn’t mean you can envision what will happen. There’s still curiosity there that makes you want to watch.) These next two click triggers are theories, and I may be stretching it a bit… Curiosity – This video is counterintuitive. Nobody willingly spends 17 hours in an airport — why would you do that? This makes people click. Negativity – There’s fear here: nobody wants to spend 17 hours in an airport. This also makes you click.

Title: The Car Loan Bubble Just Popped (HUGE Recession Indicator)
Why: Timeliness – The word “just” makes this video feel like news, and people love news. Negativity – This video is all about scary events: recessions and popping bubbles. Curiosity – Talking about the future builds curiosity, and this title ends by talking about the future.

Title: 6 Reasons Your Photos are not SHARP
Why: List – Lists make a video feel more tangible and add some curiosity. Negativity – If you’re a photographer, you definitely don’t want your photos to look “not SHARP.” This creator does a great job at grabbing her audience’s attention by calling out a specific pain point.

Title: 2 Products I Sell Every Christmas To EXPLODE My Etsy Store Sales (Holiday Print on Demand)
Why: List – Lists make a video feel more tangible and add some curiosity. Desire – Everyone in this creator’s audience would love to explode their Etsy store sales. Timeliness – Christmas is just around the corner and Etsy store owners are looking to prep for it.

Title: Can this machine help save the world?
Why:
Here are some of the other videos on this channel: We Tried 7 Simple Exercises to Strengthen our Relationship



How to Eat Less Sugar, Realistically



I Worked Out for 700 Days, Here’s How it Changed Me The audience is here because they want to save themselves, not save the world. There’s nothing wrong with that, of course. But as a creator, you need to know why your audience watches your channel and, if you want to avoid having your videos flop, make sure you’re delivering on that. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Have any questions about the hooks in this edition? Reply to this email and let me know! And if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro.

Title: 3 Feminine Habits Men Find WILDLY Attractive (Make His Heart RACE with Naturally Seductive Behavior)
Why: Curiosity – There’s contrast between “feminine” and “men” which builds curiosity and makes you do a double take. List – Lists make videos more tangible and add some curiosity. Desire – Women would love to know what these habits are that men find attractive.

Title: Van Camping in a Heat Wave 111°F
Why: Extreme – 111°F increases the stakes in this videos, which makes for a more interesting story. Negativity – People love watching videos about scary things, like camping in a dangerous heatwave.

Title: I Bought 96 Stocks, Then Did Nothing for 816 Days…
Why: Curiosity – This title opens a loop because you want to know what happens after the 816 days. Also, the thumbnail opens a loop, too, by saying, “I Didn’t Expect This…” but not specifying what “this” is. Time Frame – Time frames make videos feel more tangible, which makes them more interesting.

Title: This NEW Approach to Photography Will Change Your Career FOREVER!
Why: New opportunity – People love new opportunities because they offer hope. Curiosity – “Change your career forever” is open-ended, so it opens a loop and builds curiosity.

Title: We ALL SUCK as BEGINNERS… (The Reality of Becoming a Professional Photographer)
Why: This title used two of my favorite click triggers: negativity and calling out beginners. So why did it only get 2.8K views, while her video about a new approach to photography got 299K views? Keywords. But not in the way most people think about keywords… “We All Suck As Beginners” is too vague. It needs a keyword to let the audience (not the algorithm) know what her video is about. It could probably be better worded as “Why We All Suck As Beginner Photographers.” To add to this confusion, she’s holding a guitar and a camera in her hand. Which one is this video about? The guitar is obviously much bigger than the camera, so at first glance you might think this video is about sucking as a beginner guitar player, which is not what her channel is about. To avoid this mistake, be crystal clear on what your video is about and who it’s for, and make sure both of those align with your channel’s audience. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Title: Why Germans Don’t Buy Houses | Feli from Germany
Why: Curiosity – Buying a house is a normal, innocent behavior, so it doesn’t make sense why an entire group of people wouldn’t buy a house.

Title: 3 Bad Habits Every Poor Man Should Give Up
Why: List – Lists make a video feel more tangible and add some curiosity. Negativity – There’s a little bit of fear here that makes you want to click and find out if you have these bad habits. Specific Audience – By calling out poor men specifically in the title, it makes poor men more likely to click.

Title: Engineer Builds GREATEST Ambulance Conversion EVER!
Why: Extreme – Here’s another example of how taking it to the extreme makes for a fun video.

Title: Best 7 Work From Home Companies Currently Hiring | Remote Jobs Worldwide
Why: List – Lists make a video feel more tangible and add some curiosity. Urgency – Since this video is about companies currently hiring, there’s a bit of urgency to click now. Desire – This creator’s audience is looking for jobs at remote companies.

Title: Hilarious Fails & Bloopers from “How German Sounds Compared To Other Languages”
Why: This video probably flopped for a few reasons. First, this doesn’t really fit with the other videos on this channel. The other videos are all about differences between America and Germany or her experiences as a German in America. Second, you kinda have to have seen “How German Sounds Compared To Other Languages” to really appreciate this. This narrows down the total potential audience. Third, all of the thumbnails have her face on it, and many have the American or German flag. This doesn’t have either of the flags and it kinda has her face on it… but the mustache and wig make her less recognizable. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 6 BIG Purchases Retirees (Almost) Always Regret!
Why: List – Lists make videos feel more tangible and they add some curiosity. Negativity – Our culture is obsessed with regrets, so that word catches people’s attention and gets them to click. Specific Audience – By calling out retirees specifically in the title, retirees are way more likely to click.

Title: Raised Garden Beds Are So Yesterday!
Why: Negativity – If you currently have a raised garden bed, you probably have a little FOMO because you’re doing something that’s no longer the best. Curiosity – If raised garden beds are so yesterday, what’s the best trend to follow today?

Title: Eating The World’s Best Pizza in ITALY
Why: Epic – “The world’s best pizza” is so much cooler than “really good pizza”. Desire – The title and thumbnail are simple, but work great together to get you hungry and wanting to see more of this pizza.

Title: Building My Dream Tiny Home For Under $8000
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience would love to build their dream tiny home. Constraint – The fact that he built his dream tiny home for such a small amount of money makes for a great and intriguing story.

Title: Easy Tips for Conquering Your Fear of Flying
Why: I think this video flopped for a few reasons. First, this channel is about going on crazy travel adventures across the world. Tips for conquering your fear of flying doesn’t really fit with what her audience is looking for from her channel. Second, how many people who love traveling across the world also have a fear of flying? According to the low amount of views this video got compared to the rest on her channel, it seems like not that many. And third, most of her thumbnails are of beautiful, brightly-colored destinations, not dark plane seats. This video may have served a specific purpose and helped 14,000 people in her audience, which is great. But if you’re looking to maximize views, be sure to pick a topic that a large segment of your audience wants to hear about. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake (@jthomas__ on Twitter) P.S. Read previous editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 82hrs on Amtrak’s MOST SCENIC TRAIN! – The California Zephyr
Why: Extreme – “Most Scenic Train” is much more interesting than “One of Amtrak’s Most Scenic Trains.” Time Frame – The “82hrs” makes this video feel more tangible and gives it credibility because it’s not just a walkthrough tour — they spent a long time on the train.

Title: Top 10 Poorest Counties in the US. (Poverty=Cheap Real Estate)
Why: List – Lists make videos feel tangible and add some curiosity. Negativity – People are drawn to negative lists, like this one. When you look at this channel you see some of their highest-viewed videos are negative lists, like “10 Countries People Hate To Visit” and “Nevada’s Worst Rural Towns”. Desire – At the very end they slip in a benefit for real estate folks: “Poverty=Cheap Real Estate”

Title: 7 Things Plant Experts Do That You Probably Don’t
Why: List – Lists make videos feel tangible and add some curiosity. Authority – “Plant Experts” gives this video credibility. Curiosity – This feels like you’re getting some insider information, which builds curiosity. Negativity – “That You Probably Don’t” adds some FOMO to this title.

Title: Index Fund Investing Could Change Forever
Why: Curiosity – “Could Change Forever” builds curiosity two ways. First, it opens a loop and makes you wonder, “What will change? How will it change?” And second, it’s about the future, and people are inherently curious about the future. Negativity – The thumbnail is full of fear — the word, “worried,” and the creator with a worried expression — both of which help to grab your attention.

Title: Unboxing My New Monitor! | Apple Studio Display First Impressions
Why: Most of the videos from this channel are about new laptops and phones. New laptops and phones are sexy. Are new monitors sexy? I don’t think so. Plus, almost everybody has a laptop and phone. Not everybody has a monitor. Lesson: if you want your videos to get lots of views, pick a sexy topic that has a big potential audience. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! If you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. – Jake P.S. You can see past newsletter editions here. P.P.S. If you want to see all of the thumbnails and titles from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: What a Recession Could Mean For The Commercial Real Estate Market
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity two ways. First, it opens a loop by not answering what a recession could mean in the title, so you have to click and find out. And second, it’s talking about the future. The future is obviously unknown, so it builds curiosity. Negativity – Negative events, like recessions, get a lot of attention and clicks. Timeliness – Everybody is talking about a recession right now and this creator uses that to his advantage by riding that wave.

Title: How I Routinely Study With a Full Time Job when I’m TIRED
Why: Constraint – Studying with the constraint of a full time job makes this video way more interesting. It introduces conflict, and conflict makes for a good story. Plus, many people in this creator’s audience are struggling with trying to study with a full time job, so they relate to this title. Refute objection – “With a full time job” and “when I’m tired” are both objections that people may have when they’re trying to study. When you get rid of people’s excuses in your title, they have no excuse to not watch your video.

Title: Why Shopping Carts Have Holes + 15 Things You Never Thought About
Why: Curiosity – This title makes you feel like you’re getting in on a weird secret, and the “things you never thought about” enhances that feeling.

Title: How a Church Uses Mandalorian Tech | RED KOMODO and Unreal Engine Setup
Why: Curiosity – The contrast between “church” (which feels non-techie) and “Mandalorian tech” (which feels futuristic) builds a ton of curiosity. Authority – “Mandalorian Tech” is an amazing way to describe tech. And it’s authoritative because, well, we’re talking about The Mandalorian.

Title: A Productive Day in the Life at Cajun Koi Academy (Kuma
Why: This title feels too self-promotional. It feels like it’s all about the creator and his academy, rather than about the audience. I’m sure it made lots of money, but it might’ve been better framed as something like, “A Productive Day in the Life of a Study Expert” (his channel is about studying). Framing the video this way makes it feel like he’s aligning with the audience rather than promoting his academy. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Title: Do NOT Shut Down Your Computer! (here’s why)
Why: Negativity – This title is a warning for you to not shut down your computer. Curiosity – Shutting down your computer feels like an innocent thing to do, so this title builds curiosity because it doesn’t really make sense. It’s counterintuitive.

Title: German Neighborhoods are ILLEGAL IN AMERICA | Zoning & NIMBY-ism
Why: Negativity – “Illegal” catches your eye and makes this video more interesting. Curiosity – Like the title above, this builds curiosity because it’s a drama-filled title about a seemingly innocent thing.

Title: Things I Never Pack Travel 2022
Why: Negativity – This is about things she never packs, not things she packs. We’re drawn to warnings like this. Timeliness – Slapping the current year on the end of the title is a great way to tell your audience that this video is relevant right now.

Title: 12 digital products that can make AT LEAST $10k/month
Why: Desire – Everybody in this creator’s audience would love to have a product that earns $10K/month. List – Lists build curiosity and make a video feel more tangible.

Title: My Studio Tour 2022! Where we film & tools we use
Why: This creator’s audience watches her channel for Excel and technology tips that they can use, not for a tour of the studio where she films. Plus, most of her thumbnails have her face nice and big on the thumbnail, not a zoomed out shot of her on a couch where you can’t really tell if it’s her or not. Both the topic and thumbnail style were new. If you’re going to branch out on one of these, at least use what’s proven for the other. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Have any questions about the hooks in this edition? Reply to this email and let me know! If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: How Long Are We Going To Be In A Bear Market?
Why: Curiosity – This title builds curiosity by asking a question. Negativity – This title uses negativity because it’s talking about a negative subject — bear markets. Timeliness – Since we’re currently in a bear market, this title joins the conversation in everyone’s mind.

Title: 10 Simple Exercises To Improve Your Running
Why: List – Lists add curiosity and make videos feel more tangible. Desire – Every runner wants to improve their running, and they’d also love to do it with simple exercises. Time Frame – The thumbnail includes a short, 10-minute time frame, which makes improving your running feel more achievable.

Title: 5 THINGS ORGANIZED PEOPLE DO (That You Don’t )
Why: Authority – Organized people have credibility here and this creator’s audience would love to be more like them. List – Lists add curiosity and make videos feel more tangible. Negativity – Finishing this title with “(That You Don’t)” gives you a little fomo. Curiosity – The thumbnail builds curiosity by opening up a loop.

Title: How to Instantly Make Anyone Respect You
Why: Desire – Not only is this video about something this audience wants (respect), but it also promises to help them get it instantly.

Title: How This Pro Runner Handles Race Anxiety
Why: This title has some good things going for it — authority and a pain point. So why did it flop? I think it’s because the pain point is only shared by a few people. Or maybe most people experience it so few times that by the time they see this video on their home page, they don’t care or have forgotten about it. Contrast this title with something like, “How This Pro Runner Handles Getting Tired While Running.” Everyone experiences this pain point, and they experience it every time they go for a run, so it’d probably get more views. The next time you make a video about a pain point, make sure that there’s enough demand for the video. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Follow me on Twitter for more title tips @jthomas__​ P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Most Underrated Pieces of Backpacking Equipment: Inexpensive Gear That Makes a Difference
Why: Curiosity – There’s contrast (which adds curiosity) between “inexpensive gear” that “makes a difference.” And “underrated” adds to the curiosity, too. Desire – This creator’s audience loves good gear.

Title: this is the EASIEST way to find your style (no shopping required!)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience would love to find their style and do it the easiest way. Refute an Objection – The audience might be thinking they don’t have time or money to go shopping, but this title gets rid of that excuse.

Title: 3-MUST DO-Daily Strength Exercises For Seniors
Why: List – Lists build curiosity and make a video feel more tangible. Desire – This creator’s audience is looking for strength exercises to help them stay active. Daily Tips – People seem to really like exercises or habits you can plug into your daily routine. Specific Audience – If you’re a senior and you see this title, you feel like this video was made specifically for you, so you’re more likely to click.

Title: 15 Websites That Will Pay You DAILY Within 24 Hours (Easy Work At Home Jobs)
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience would love to make money daily and get an easy work at home job. List – Lists build curiosity and make a video feel more tangible. Time Frame – The time frame in this title refutes an objection. Many websites take a while to pay you, but this promises to tell you about websites that pay within 24 hours. Daily Tips – Another title with a daily benefit here.

Title: A Simple Day In My Life  How I Build an Outfit, Life Updates, What’s New In My Wardrobe
Why:
This title is all about the creator and has four different subjects, so it’s not as punchy. Plus, it’s about a simple day in her life — there’s no conflict, which is what makes a good story. Contrast this title with some of the others on her channel: “If I was starting my wardrobe from scratch, these are the pieces I’d buy (minimalist wardrobe)”



“What I learned by getting rid of 60% of my clothes ”



“7 things I cut from my budget that I don’t miss at all (where I spend & where I save)” These are more focused, have more emotion, and talk about pain points or desires the audience has. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Have any questions about the hooks in this edition? Reply to this email and let me know! And if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please forward this email to them and send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake P.S. Follow me on Twitter for more title tips @jthomas__​ P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: START Fishing A KEITECH Like This (Don’t FALL Behind)
Why: Curiosity – “Like This” opens a loop and makes you wonder how to fish a keitech. Negativity – The “don’t fall behind” part at the end adds a warning.

Title: Just Permitted 56 Acres to make $50,000/month
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience would love to make $50,000/month. Timeliness – Starting out with “Just” makes you feel like this video is about a new thing that just happened. It’s kinda mixing news and education together.

Title: Where does the POWER in the GOLF SWING Come From???
Why: Curiosity – The title builds curiosity by asking a question. This audience may assume the answer is legs, but the thumbnail adds to the curiosity by showing a guy sitting down and not using his legs. Desire – Most golfers would love to have more power in their swing.

Title: BROKE AF? Start w/ Zero Make $250 a day online (DO THIS)
Why: Curiosity – This title starts by asking a question to build curiosity, then finishes by opening a loop to build even more. Negativity – “Broke AF” is a big pain point many people in this creator’s audience have. Desire – This creator’s audience would love to make $250 a day online. Beginner Tips – If you’re a beginner starting from zero, you feel like this video was made for you.

Title: DON’T Fish Like Everyone Else (Fish The EXTREMES)
Why: This title was good in that it’s got a warning and kinda opens a loop. But I think it flopped because it doesn’t speak to any real fear or desire. The audience doesn’t fear fishing like everyone else — they fear not catching fish. And they don’t care about fishing the extremes — they want to catch fish. Don’t try to be too clever with your titles and always think about what your audience wants. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Have any questions about the hooks in this edition? Reply to this email and let me know! And if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from every Creator Hooks edition in one place, check out creatorhookspro.com. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 21 Ways You Are Hurting Your Cat Without Realizing
Why: List – Lists make a video more tangible (you know exactly what the video is about) and build curiosity. Negativity – Nobody wants to accidentally hurt their cat, so they watch this video to avoid doing that. Curiosity – Lists about negative things build lots of curiosity because you ask yourself, “Am I doing any of these?” and you’ve gotta watch to find out.

Title: WARNING: Bad News For Amazon Sellers
Why: Negativity – Warnings work really well to get our attention and get us to click. Authority – Jeff Bezos’ shiny bald head is easily recognizable and quickly gets the audience’s attention.

Title: Asking YOUNG Millionaires How to be Successful
Why: Desire – Everyone in this creator’s audience wants to know how to be successful Authority – This creator is asking authority figures (young millionaires) how they did it. Curiosity – You really want to see what these young millionaires say, so you’ve gotta watch this video.

Title: THIS Simple Trick Makes Your Bathroom & Toilet SMELL AMAZING!
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience (and probably — hopefully — most people) would like to have their bathroom and toilet smell good. This title also promises a lot (an amazing-smelling bathroom) for a little (a simple trick). Curiosity – This title opens a loop by telling you there’s a simple trick to make your bathroom and toilet smell amazing, but not what that simple trick is.

Title: How to Cut and Dice a MANGO!  (real simple and fast life hacks)
Why: The videos on this channel are mostly about cleaning and house hacks, not so much cooking and kitchen hacks. Cutting and dicing a mango may be a great topic, but it doesn’t seem like it’s a great topic for this channel. So when picking your next video topic, make sure you’re giving your audience what they really want to hear from YOU. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Title: 10 Mixing Tips That Changed My Life
Why: List – Lists make it easy to understand what the video is about and builds curiosity. Desire – “Changed my life” is a strong desire that many people have.

Title: HOW TO APPLY FOUNDATION FOR BEGINNERS | NINA UBHI
Why: Beginner Tips – Beginners are the biggest, hungriest subset of any audience. Desire – A big portion of this creator’s audience wants to learn how to apply foundation perfectly.

Title: I no longer VLOOKUP(), I use this other function instead…
Why: Negativity – This video is about stopping using a common function. Curiosity – Since VLOOKUP is a common and useful function, it’s counterintuitive to stop using it. Plus, this title opens up a loop at the end by not telling you what the other function is.

Title: 8 Mind-Blowing Websites You Probably Didn’t Know Existed
Why: List – Have I told you lists make it easy to understand what the video is about and build curiosity? Curiosity – Describing these websites as “mind-blowing” and that “you probably didn’t know existed” builds curiosity.

Title: MY GO TO BEAUTY TOOLS AND MONTHLY SKINCARE REGIME 2022 | NINA UBHI
Why: I think this video flopped because of the word “and”. Most successful videos are about a single topic, but this video is about two topics. In your titles, you want to make a big promise and deliver on it. When you start including multiple topics in your title you confuse your audience. And if you confuse you lose. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Have any questions about the hooks in this edition? Reply to this email and let me know! And if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please forward this email to them and send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake P.S. Follow me on Twitter for more title tips @jthomas__​ P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Will The Housing Market Crash By The End of The Year? – What banks don’t want you to know
Why: Curiosity – This title starts off building curiosity with a question, and then at the end opens a loop with the phrase, “What banks don’t want you to know.” Negativity – This video is about the housing market crash and about what banks don’t want you to know… lots of fear and conspiracy in there. Timeliness – This video does particularly well because the housing market crash is a hot topic right now. Time Frame – By limiting the scope of this video to just the end of the year, it makes it more tangible and even gives some urgency for you to watch it. Authority – Banks are an authority in this space, and this title makes them an enemy, which makes you want to watch it even more.

Title: Unlocking Lightroom’s Darkest Editing Secret!
Why: Curiosity – Unlocking a secret builds a ton of curiosity, plus there’s contrast between Lightroom and darkest secret. Negativity – “Lightroom’s Darkest Secret” has a lot of drama and conspiracy vibes. Beginner tips – The thumbnail mentions beginners.

Title: Everything I Spend Money On For My 7-Figure Blog | Blogging Expenses
Why: Curiosity – You feel like you’re getting in on a secret because you’re learning about where she spends her money, which can be a taboo subject. Desire – This creator’s audience would love to have a 7-figure blog.

Title: Voice Typing Changes Everything – So much more than Dictation!
Why: Curiosity – “Changes everything” opens a loop and makes you wonder how does it change everything and what changes. New Opportunity – New technology is exciting because it promises something different. We don’t have any previous bad experiences with it, so there’s a lot of hope.

Title: Breaking Down the Story Structure of Jurassic Park
Why:
The videos that perform best on this channel are about visual effects: Color Grading 101 – Everything You Need to Know



We Recreated a Shot from Obi-Wan Kenobi



Destroyed City Effect From Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness But this video is about storytelling. It’s good to try new things on your channel, but know that when you do, the video may flop. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Have any questions about the hooks in this edition? Reply to this email and let me know! And if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please forward this email to them and send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake P.S. Follow me on Twitter for more title tips @jthomas__​ P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: 3 Major Ways To Earn Over $100,000 Per Month In Jamaica To Supplement Your 9-5 Income || ANNA NOVIA
Why: Too good to be true – This video is not only about a desire everybody wants, but it’s about a desire that sounds almost too good to be true (another example coming later in this edition). List – People love clicking on list videos. Specific audience – If you live in Jamaica, you might feel like this video was made specifically for you, so you’re more likely to click and watch.

Title: how to change your life: 10 daily habits for 2022 *watch this if you’re feeling stuck*
Why: Desire – Many people would love to change their lives, and for those who do, most want to do so really bad. List – People like clicking on list videos. Daily tips – We’ve got more daily tips here, and daily habits are attractive because we can just plug them into our routine and not worry about when or how often to do them. Timeliness – “In 2022” lets the audience know that this is what’s working right now.

Title: How to Write Off 100% of Your Car as a Business [STEP-BY-STEP] | Vehicle Tax Deduction | Sec. 179
Why: Too good to be true – This sounds too good to be true, which makes it more interesting and exciting.

Title: This Paint Trick Will Make CHEAP WHITE PAINT Cover + Hide As Well As The Most Expensive Brands!
Why: Benefit – This video is about a benefit for the audience and it promises a lot for a little, which makes it more exciting. Curiosity – This title opens a loop by mentioning there’s a trick, but not telling you what the trick is.

Title: GARBAGE DISPOSAL NOT WORKING?! Try These Easy Fixes! (3 Sink Disposal Repairs…More Tips + Tricks!)
Why:
This title is more geared for search and will probably do well in the long term, but if you don’t have this specific problem right now, you’re probably not going to watch this video. That’s not the case with some of the other videos on this channel, like: NAILS vs. SCREWS…Which Should You Choose?!



Does SELF-PRIMING PAINT Really Work…Or Is It A Marketing Gimmick?



The Truth About PARTICLE BOARD…Is It The Worst Material?! Also, it seems like this creator’s audience might be more interested in building things than fixing things. This is a bit of a tough one to nail down why it flopped, but two lessons we can learn from it: Have a strategy for your video (i.e. browse vs. search) and have proper expectations for it



Get to know your audience and why they really watch your channel Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Have any questions about the hooks in this edition? Reply to this email and let me know! And if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please forward this email to them and send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake P.S. Follow me on Twitter for more title tips @jthomas__​ P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro. Read last week’s edition »

Title: Affordable Cities: 10 US Metro Areas With Underrated Livability, Walkability and Transit
Why: Curiosity – The word “underrated” makes this title more fun and interesting, and “absurdly undervalued” in the thumbnail reiterates that. Desire – Many people would love to move to a more affordable city, or one with better livability, walkability and transit. Timeliness – With a recession looming and housing prices sky high, everybody has the word “affordable” on their mind right now. List – People like clicking on list videos.

Title: How I Would Learn To Code (If I Could Start Over)
Why: Beginner tips – People love “if I could start over” stories. It meets your audience where they’re at. It’s mostly for beginners, and beginners are the biggest and hungriest subset of any audience.

Title: 5 Dog Training Exercises You Should Do EVERY DAY At Home!
Why: List – People love clicking on list videos. Daily tips – People love things they can do every day because they’re easy to just plug into your routine.

Title: TOP 8 Dividend ETFs For Passive Income in 2022 (High Yield)
Why: List – Another list video here! Desire – Almost everyone in the world loves passive income. Timeliness – “In 2022” lets you know these dividend ETFs can give you passive income right now.

Title: Teaching Abused And Terrified Dog To Stop Jumping In One Session
Why: This title is too wordy. When you read it, it takes you too much time to understand what the video is about because the hook is buried behind too many words. This creator should’ve used “abused” or “terrified” in the title to make it shorter, not both of them. Plus, the thumbnail is confusing. I would’ve expected the jumping dog to be on the left and the well-behaved dog on the right. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Have any questions about the hooks in this edition? Reply to this email and let me know! And if you know a fellow creator who needs help with writing better titles, please forward this email to them and send them to creatorhooks.com. Here’s to the war on boring content. – Jake P.S. Follow me on Twitter for more title tips @jthomas__​ P.P.S. If you want to see all of the videos from Creator Hooks in one place, check out Creator Hooks Pro.

Title: 3 Habits That Will Make You A Beast In Matches
Why: List – People love clicking on lists. Desire – This audience would love to become a beast in matches.

Title: 9 DECORATING MISTAKES THAT COULD MAKE YOU DEPRESSED OR ANXIOUS
Why: List – We’ve got another list here. Negativity – There are several aspects of negativity here. This video is about mistakes, and the result is you being depressed or anxious. The thumbnail reinforces the negativity by calling your home depressing.

Title: Swim without getting tired
Why: Benefit – Swimmers (this creator’s audience) would love to swim without getting tired. Refute an objection – This video refutes the “I can’t swim too long because I get too tired,” objection, so you’ve gotta watch and see how to do it. Great thumbnail – This thumbnail shows a clear contrast and progression to helping the audience achieve their goal that the title promises.

Title: The Intelligent Investor’s Road to $1,000,000
Why: Desire – Making $1,000,000 is a huge goal for this channel’s audience. Beginner tips – The thumbnail text tells you this is for beginners because it says “An investor’s first $1,000,000.”

Title: Minimalist Kitchen Essentials | My traveling kitchen setup.
Why: The majority of this creator’s audience probably cooks in their own kitchen. They don’t have or need a traveling kitchen setup, so they won’t watch this video. To avoid this mistake, really think about who your audience is and how you can serve them best. Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks! Title: How Did MINAS ITHIL Become MINAS MORGUL? | Middle-Earth Lore
Why: Curiosity – This title is a question, which evokes curiosity. Negativity – Minas Morgul is an evil city, and people love hearing about villains. Story – This video talks about changing from a good city to a bad city, so there’s a story behind it.

Title: Neuroscientist: “Never Feel Tired During The Day” | Andrew Huberman
Why: Authority – Authority works because we know and trust authority figures. This title uses authority two ways: it uses his position (neuroscientist) and his name (Andrew Huberman). Negativity – The quote is about moving away from pain — never feeling tired — instead of moving toward pleasure, i.e. feeling energized. Desire – I, and I feel like I’m speaking for everybody reading this, would love to never feel tired during the day.

Title: how i plan to reinvent myself and change my life in one year | level up
Why: Desire – This creator’s audience would love to reinvent themselves and change their lives. Time frame – “In One Year” makes reinventing yourself and changing your life seem more achievable and tangible. Change Your Life – I’ve seen the term “change my life” come up a lot in this newsletter. People know what they have and they’re not satisfied, so “change your life” is so powerful.

Title: The Recession That Will Change A Generation
Why: Negativity – This video is about a negative event, a recession, plus the thumbnail text talks about the end of an era with a scary-looking graph. Timeliness – This video rides a current trend because everyone is talking about a recession. Change – Although this isn’t about changing your life, here’s the word change again. Change helps open a loop, which makes your curious, and starts a story.

Title: Let’s Discuss ADAPTING TOLKIEN! (Ft. The Script Department) | Middle-Earth Lore
Why: Let’s get this out of the way first — this video is a podcast video, whereas most of the videos on this channel are voiceovers with cool animations and clips from the movies. That was probably a big reason why it flopped. But the title was also different. “Let’s Discuss” has no real benefit, fear, or curiosity, it’s just a plain statement. These creators should’ve taken the most interesting point in the interview and used that for the title, instead of leading with a bland “Let’s Discuss.” Alright, that wraps up this week’s Creator Hooks!
